- http://logs.openstack.org/20333/4/check/gate-nova-pylint/7391 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-01 14:52:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I still think this needs to be broken up."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:47:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Thank you for the explanation. Based on the description I have some concerns with tying this to block device mapping. I think this would be far more useful as an independent command that operates on a single block device.

Most of the time, your cinder volumes will be on different nodes from the instance. For example:

 hosta  hostb  hostc
  vola
       \
         inst 
              \
               volb

If you need to take one of the nodes down in this situation, the existing code doesn't really help you. In this case you really want to be able to do:
 a) put hosta in maintenance mode so it gets no new volumes
 b) create a new volc (not on host a)
 c) migrate the data from vola to volc (leave the instance)
 d) shutdown node a

Doing all of this as part of a block migration is only useful if the volume and the instance is on the same node. Therefore I think this needs to be refactored into a new command that just migrates a single volume. Then the block migration can be done separately if necessary."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:47:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 6124, 'date': '2013-02-04 11:36:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi Vish, some comments on your reply.

"Doing all of this as part of a block migration is only useful if the volume and the instance is on the same node"

Instance and the "attached volumes" can be on different nodes. This is implemented by the patched.

"Therefore I think this needs to be refactored into a new command that just migrates a single volume. Then the block migration can be done separately if necessary."

This patch (and blueprint) was intended for migration of in-use volumes because libvirt's migrateToURI handles live copying and syncing of attached volumes.

Migration of volumes "in-use" (case 1) and those that are "un-attached" (case 2) should be managed separately.

I have started a mailing list thread on openstack-dev. Please check it out for more detailed discussion,

(http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-February/005345.html)'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-12 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-12 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2013-05-06 22:36:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Please specify in the commit message that it includes implementations for libvirt, xenapi and fake drivers only.'}]

commit_message:
Add Support for Cinder Volume migration

* Adds support for cinder volume migration during live block migration
* Uses symlinks in instance-xx dir to cinder volumes /dev/disk/by-path
* Copies currently attached volumes to new volumes specified using
  --block-device-mapping flag for "nova live-migration" command

Blueprint migrate-volume-block-migration

Change-Id: Iab8dc4f3a2754b493bc218e18aacca706c4e28ff

[{'created': '2013-06-07 12:32:36.000000000', 'message': "Redhat family doesn't have dbus service

The DBUS service in RHEL/CentOS/Fedora is actually called messgebus,
so the libvirt recipe doesn't work properly. This fixes that.

Change-Id: Icfb442589eee3dc960b495f82bad82de19db9e74
"}]
commit_message:
Redhat family doesn't have dbus service

The DBUS service in RHEL/CentOS/Fedora is actually called messgebus,
so the libvirt recipe doesn't work properly. This fixes that.

Change-Id: Icfb442589eee3dc960b495f82bad82de19db9e74

paramas and headers. This patch ensures those params are correctly
encoded before the request is made.

The patch adds strutils from oslo and updates gettextutils.

Fixes bug: #1182824

commit_message:
Encode headers and params

BaseClient currently fails when non-ascii characters are passed in
paramas and headers. This patch ensures those params are correctly
encoded before the request is made.

The patch adds strutils from oslo and updates gettextutils.

Fixes bug: #1182824

(cherry-picked: db33d99af2b16ae81f815c63a6aea851318a2b34)

Conflicts:
	openstack-common.conf

Change-Id: I12fc2d93b10c43091c1e921be2db1258beb18439

commit_message:
Use strainer to isolate and test individual cookbooks

Included:
- Add strainer gem
- Update test-related gems
- Add Strainer file
- Remove run_tests.bash
- Update .gitignore
- Update README file

Partial fix for bug 1188345

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-29 10:32:34.000000000', 'message': "Prevent E500 when listing with null values

An image may have NULL values for 'name', 'disk_format' and
'container_format'.

Various image list operations which used a marker could return
an E500 because:

* sqlalchemy db: an illegal statement would be formed
* simple db: the sort function would error when it hit a null

To prevent this we change the behaviour so that when a NULL
is encountered we treat it as an emptry string ('') for the
purposes of sorting. This is consistent with the behaviour
for listing the db contents using 'sql order by'.

It is safe to provide the default empty string in all cases
since only string based 'sort_key' values can be NULL in the
database, ie 'size' (not a string) cannot be NULL, and
'deleted_at' (a string) is not a supported sort_key.

Fixes bug 1183860.

Change-Id: I2187c41a3fab8b5813ba3a5e0f3249ee5dd981ed
"}, {'created': '2013-05-29 10:45:42.000000000', 'message': "Prevent E500 when listing with null values

commit_message:
Prevent E500 when listing with null values

An image may have NULL values for 'name', 'disk_format' and
'container_format'.

Various image list operations which used a marker could return
an E500 because:

* sqlalchemy db: an illegal statement would be formed
* simple db: the sort function would error when it hit a null

To prevent this we change the behaviour so that when a NULL
is encountered we treat it as an emptry string ('') for the
purposes of sorting. This is consistent with the behaviour
for listing the db contents using 'sql order by'.

It is safe to provide the default empty string in all cases
since only string based 'sort_key' values can be NULL in the
database, eg 'size' (not a string) cannot be NULL.

Fixes bug 1183860.

Change-Id: I2187c41a3fab8b5813ba3a5e0f3249ee5dd981ed

commit_message:
Fix bug in port creation form

'network_name' is not a recognized Quantum attribute, so passing it
in the request to the Quantum Server causes an error. In the end this
is not required because the network is identified by its id. So
this patch removes it (as it's done in other cases as well).

Fixes bug #1187129

Change-Id: Ie18c7bd504f8c241d002d6a050b8bcc59ed9fc03

commit_message:
Remove floating CLI from compute admin

Remove the section on how to use floating IPs from compute admin,
add a link to the OpenStack Clients guide instead.

Change-Id: Ie870fa31ac9b5257333a3504c2f6fe136ebcde93

[{'created': '2013-06-04 21:10:11.000000000', 'message': "Quantum: under the hood details

Add a chapter in Network Admin guide that describes how the Open
vSwitch plugin and Linux bridging plugins configure the various
network devices on the compute and networking hosts.

All of the images and code are from Etsuji Nakai (Red Hat) from the
slides:

http://www.slideshare.net/enakai/how-quantum-configures-virtual-networks-under-the-hood

This content has been added to the docs with Etsuji's permission, and
he has been recorded as author of this commit.

Lorin added some supporting text and specified (guessed) at the config
file options.

Change-Id: Ie2ce069b025bde273c20c8324317af24ddd4d019

Quantum: under the hood details

Add a chapter in Network Admin guide that describes how the Open
vSwitch plugin and Linux bridging plugins configure the various
network devices on the compute and networking hosts.

All of the images and code are from Etsuji Nakai (Red Hat) from the
slides:

http://www.slideshare.net/enakai/how-quantum-configures-virtual-networks-under-the-hood

This content has been added to the docs with Etsuji's permission, and
he has been recorded as author of this commit.

Lorin added some supporting text and specified (guessed) at the config
file options.

Change-Id: Ie2ce069b025bde273c20c8324317af24ddd4d019

commit_message:
Allow drivers to set DHCP boot options.

Allow virt drivers (eg. baremetal) to specify DHCP PXE boot options
which are then passed out via the network API.

Fixes bug 1180454

Change-Id: Ib3ec89ebc2f15e5c0cb26def46bd862fb2da13ec

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-03-12 15:35:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Won't any sort of change to the default here risk totally breaking an upgrade?"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2013-03-12 15:56:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Did you mean to put a different bug in the commit message? This bug seems unrelated.

Otherwise, I'm happy with the patch. Russell, can't anyone following code make sure things work by placing the old value into their confif files until they fix up anything that the new value may break? Is this not a good enough solution?"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-03-12 16:59:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hmmmm, thinking about this more I think the answer is "possibly". It depends on if any distro out there is already returning the FQDN for a call to gethostname(). In my tests Fedora and Ubuntu behave differently here for example.

We could wrap this in a flag. Something like --truncatehostname. Do you think that would help?'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-03-12 17:02:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Trey, that's the correct bug. I reverted their original fix yesterday because it caused some knock-on breakages."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2013-03-12 18:10:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

removing -1. I'm fine with either changing the default and publicly documenting the change, or adding a new config for truncating the hostname. commit_message:
Configurable hostname length.

DocImpact: Windows and Linux return different things for a call to
socket.gethostname() (either FQDN or not). This method normalizes
the output to make running mixed environments easier.

The big goal here is to not changing the current default behaviour,
whilst allowing deployments to do something different without
having to set a customized flag on every machine. Therefore, the
default value for the new hostname_length flag is "system", which
will do whatever was happening before. If you want FQDNs, then you
should change that flag to "full". For just the host portion of the
name, use "short".

There's a lot of code churn here to handle the fact that we can't
use the value of a flag to help us calculate the value of the flag.

Resolves bug 1055503.

Change-Id: I13a40c7746f084250b3ad7c2e21900dcd8df666f

I wouldn't be too hasty in removing so called "discontinued" versions of a distro. IME, people have a tendency to keep using them for much longer than you'd expect, and by removing support from devstack we'd probably just create more bug reports against devstack. As long as the old distro's aren't placing an unacceptable maintenance burden on the devstack code, we should just let them stay indefinitely.

Better yet would be to change the syntax used for these conditional RPM lines, so we can specify a range of distros. eg rather than listing  f16,f17,f18,f19, it would be nicer if we could do  "fedora >= 16" as the dep. That is rather more work than this fix though, so can wait for another day.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-05-21 12:51:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Users are well aware of when a distro is still pre-release. Requiring FORCE=yes just puts an useless annoying roadblock in the way of getting work done.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:21:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

[{'created': '2013-05-20 15:12:50.000000000', 'message': 'Make devstack work on Fedora 19 and Fedora 20 (rawhide)

Current devstack prints

 "this script has not been tested on f19"

And passing FORCE=yes results in failure. The reason for
the failure is that various RPMs are annotated to only
be installed on f16/f17/f18. Extend these annotations to
include 'f19' and 'f20' to make Fedora 19 and Fedora 20
(current rawhide) work.

Change-Id: I41fd425c0c5016f59b9fb1a4252aaac71e21a0de
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Make devstack work on Fedora 19 and Fedora 20 (rawhide)

Current devstack prints

 "this script has not been tested on f19"

And passing FORCE=yes results in failure. The reason for
the failure is that various RPMs are annotated to only
be installed on f16/f17/f18. Extend these annotations to
include 'f19' and 'f20' to make Fedora 19 and Fedora 20
(current rawhide) work.

Change-Id: I41fd425c0c5016f59b9fb1a4252aaac71e21a0de
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

- http://logs.openstack.org/26845/4/check/gate-keystone-python26/3618 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26845/4/check/gate-keystone-python26-rhel6/198 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/26845/4/check/gate-keystone-python27/3629 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26845/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/12679 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26845/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/12394 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26845/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/18533 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26845/4/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/617 : FAILURE (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-04-23 02:40:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

These need to be tested and confirmed against MySQL and PostgreSQL.  Please run test_sql_upgrade against these backends and confirm that the test passes.

Information here might be helpful
http://adam.younglogic.com/2013/04/database-tests-keystone/

You can use Devstack to set up both of the databases for you.  After devstack run, drop and recreate the databases prior to running the tests.'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2013-04-24 18:08:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

are we explicitly doing selects on multiple objects where are checking expires and valid? i think most of our calls are for a single token in which case we can just check this in code

the bug linked doesn't explain where the poor performance is coming from, but there are a bunch of existing causes for extremely poor performance that are unrelated to indexing.

please include an actual performance evaluation of this change for the calls you think it affects"}, {'account_id': 7141, 'date': '2013-04-26 08:21:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

with the PKI context, keystone tokens is quite big. So with a little number of records in the table of tokens the size on the disk can be high. And in this function _list_tokens_for_trust there are filters on valid and expires fields.

in my test, with a number of token of 50 000 the size of the database is more than 250Mo. Before adding indexes, each auth request takes more than one second, with indexes it's close to 0."}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2013-04-26 20:38:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

_list_tokens_for_trust is going away. In general people should not be using list operations for much at all (this seems to have been forgotten at some point). In general tokens should not be listed, and when trusts is moved, appropriately, to an extension instead of adding on to the tokens table they should be keeping track of their own indexes rather than trying to jam them into the tokens table.

Is there another call that is affected?'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-04-27 01:08:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

termie, the reason we enumerate tokens is so we can delete them later.  In the case of the trust, if either the trustor or trustee  user account gets disabled, we need to be able to delete the users tokens.

If we provide a scorecard, or some other mechanism instead of enumerating them, the trusts code (and oauth, and any other token generating mechanism) will need to work with it to make sure tokens get invalidated when they should.  So, I am guessing we are going to somehow revers  the current approach, and indicate on a scorecard or some other record that "when deleting this token, also delete all of those?"'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2013-04-29 18:13:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

ayoung: the goal for the places you are currently enumerating things is to have previously issued tokens be invalidated as an atomic side effect of updating the user object, we talked about this at the summit, morgan is looking into it'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-05-02 16:19:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Just marking the tokens as invalid is insufficient:  we need to generate a list of the invalid tokens to hand over to the remote systems that verify the tokens using PKI.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-05-02 16:21:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 6460, 'date': '2013-05-02 21:03:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

My guess is something like ceilometer would like to collect metrics on expired and valid one day.  So I could see this being used beyond just trusts.   Seems  like it's a small amount of extra code to maintain with some nice upside for performance benefits (according to Sylvain performance data) when something needs to access this information.  I already know of one scenario where this type of information was being tracked as part of stress testing / performance benchmarks"}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-08 23:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(2 inline comments)

would be interesting to see some actual performance numbers to see what affect this has.'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2013-05-09 19:09:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Do not merge

some discussion on irc regarding revocation lists with ayoung may have changed his mind a little on this.

in general i do not take any modifications to the database lightly, at this point i don't think sylvain is establishing sufficient reason to change this (only pointing out performance improvements for calls that should be removed)"}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-09 19:24:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Interestingly, I was working on a system where this fix would have been useful (as a workaround) today. The test was for stability/scalability, so it was running for several hours booting instances. Keystone's token table got to about 1 million rows, mostly because nova using quantum creates a new token for every quantum op as far as I can tell. Eventually, getting the revoked tokens list takes ~9 seconds, and then nova fails because quantum's getting token times out (so they blame Keystone of course). Creating the index made it so that the query to get the revoked tokens list now takes < 1 second."}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-09 20:06:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

termie - the blueprint only mentions the memcache and kvs backends, so that doesn't apply to this review for the sql backend.

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/clock-for-revoke-tokens

After thinking about this more, I think it's the right thing to do for the sql tokens table, unless we're going to rewrite something."}, {'account_id': 7141, 'date': '2013-05-13 15:58:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

See ayoung patch, https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28859/'}, {'account_id': 7141, 'date': '2013-05-16 12:02:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

See ayoung patch, https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28859/'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-16 18:08:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

restore? ayoung's change appears to address an entirely different issue"}, {'account_id': 7141, 'date': '2013-05-17 09:01:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I think the ayoung's patch by moving the revoked tokens covers the most part of this issue since only  valid tokens will be in the table. So I can re-open this fix if we want to get an improvement on the expires field. let me know what you think about ?"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-17 16:30:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

absolutely, i'd be happy to see this split into a couple patches with more limited scope"}, {'account_id': 7141, 'date': '2013-05-23 07:53:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Restored

Since the patch of ayoung https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28859/ is not merged, this patch could be a good start to improve performance with few modifications'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-07 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-07 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

Add indexes to SQL token Backends

Add migration script to add indexes to expires and valid columns.

Change-Id: Ia1fb9c3b1253e2b1135f831ac0aea96b8e69446e
Fixes: bug #1168399

was a reference and contained no content required for a basic deployment,
we are removing it until someone automates the process of generating
something equivalent, as discussed in the bug.

Change-Id: Ic56d8bd95d4b156905547c5f7f16c57645e0c810
'}]
commit_message:
Remove outdated appendix listing all config options.

bug 1157031

These config options had not been updated for grizzly. As this appendix
was a reference and contained no content required for a basic deployment,
we are removing it until someone automates the process of generating
something equivalent, as discussed in the bug.

Change-Id: Ic56d8bd95d4b156905547c5f7f16c57645e0c810

Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1812, 'name': 'p-draigbrady', 'email': 'P@draigBrady.com', 'username': 'p-draigbrady'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 4395, 'name': 'Aaron Rosen', 'email': 'aaronorosen@gmail.com', 'username': 'arosen'}, {'_account_id': 5441, 'name': 'Andrew Laski', 'email': 'andrew@lascii.com', 'username': 'alaski'}, {'_account_id': 5652, 'name': 'David Ripton', 'email': 'dripton@redhat.com', 'username': 'dripton'}, {'_account_id': 6950, 'name': 'Kashi Reddy', 'email': 'kashi.reddy@rackspace.com', 'username': 'kashivreddy'}, {'_account_id': 7494, 'name': 'Guangya Liu', 'email': 'gyliu513@gmail.com', 'username': 'JayLau'}, {'_account_id': 7531, 'name': 'Sridevi Koushik', 'email': 'sridevi.koushik@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sridevik'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 20:23:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 20:24:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 20:27:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 20:28:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2013-05-15 20:37:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 20:38:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Still a WIP...  thinking I should add more tests.  But I'm curious to see what jenkins thinks first."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-05-15 20:45:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thinking out loud, may be incorrect

What this would end up doing is firing the requests at the same time at the SDN backend. In our case, NVP has a tendency to tell the requesting service to go away and come back later (no actual time to wait is returned despite the docs saying it will, btw) I worry a little that this will just compound that effect and the async won't buy us anything

Another potential issue is someone could introduce code in the build process somewhere that gets network info, and we wouldn't be able to tell until we've deployed it.

Neither of these are reasons not to deploy. Just thinking through some possible edge cases."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:08:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

There should be no change to the amount of requests fired at the same time... as multiple instance builds in parallel already cause parallel queries.  (If I understand your first point correctly that this is your concern).

For #2, yeah.  Someone could certainly try to make a separate query for network info to find that it is not allocated yet when it expects it to be... and it may not be completely obvious that there's a background thread retrieving the info.  But people can screw up code in all sorts of other ways, too.  :)  If someone did add a 2nd query like this, even in the old code, it would be a waste of a call when the network info would have already been retrieved.  They should just use the model already returned.  And in my patch, if they do use it earlier, it will ensure the response is received.  Did I understand this point correctly, too?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:13:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29288/5/check/gate-nova-pep8/25954 : SUCCESS in 3m 07s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29288/5/check/gate-nova-docs/20172/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 33s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29288/5/check/gate-nova-python26/21578 : SUCCESS in 12m 15s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29288/5/check/gate-nova-python27/21668 : SUCCESS in 8m 46s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29288/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/16165 : SUCCESS in 40m 04s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29288/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/15881 : FAILURE in 43m 51s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/29288/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/22665 : SUCCESS in 20m 54s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29288/5/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/3779 : FAILURE in 9m 23s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/29288/5/check/gate-nova-pylint/11573 : SUCCESS in 7m 53s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:14:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This pleases me. If possible I would like for compute to make sure that the network_info has been populated (probably at the last second) by accessing it before passing it to virt so we don't end up with a lookup failure being noticed at the virt level instead of in the compute manager where it should have been noticed.."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:44:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Trey: That would defeat the purpose of this patch, since we almost immediately call the virt layer.  The long-running operations are in virt... downloading image, etc.  So we want this to be running in the background during that time.

But yeah, that's a potential difference here.  If the allocation fails, the exception will not be raised until later.

Note that the virt layers which still require legacy info don't gain much benefit here... as the call to model.legacy() ends up waiting for the allocate to complete.  So for libvirt right now, there's not much change here.  For xenapi, there'll be a noticeable benefit."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-16 16:02:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 7494, 'date': '2013-05-16 16:05:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Allocate networks in the background

Setting up networks and allocating IP addresses has the potential to
take an undesirable amount of time, blocking the build of a new
instance.  We can parallelize some work by querying for this information
*while* a new instance is being provisioned in the virt driver.

This adds a wrapper around the NetworkInfo model which allows one to
query for network information in a greenthread.  When a code path is hit
that actually needs the network information, it waits for the
greenthread to finish, if it hasn't already.

Network allocation will only be async for virt drivers that accept this
NetworkInfo model.  Other drivers that expect the legacy format end up
waiting for the operation to complete before driver.spawn is called.

Implements blueprint async-network-alloc

Change-Id: I389f939b9a36bc20b3b66e98d006d694622bd963

get rid of no-op __init__ methods

There were a lot of __init__ methods that simply called their super()
with nothing else.

commit_message:
Unset all stubs before running other cleanups.

Cleanup callbacks are run in reverse order so all stubs unsetting
should be added at the end of the cleanup list.

Fixes bug 1185004

Change-Id: I5ad3ea2cdce663aaeae6b7cc2cb9c5dac9d12435

commit_message:
Import eventlet patch from oslo.

This was abandoned once before: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25781/

However this is not to do with packaging. This is required if we use
eventlet subprocess module (like we should be) in jenkins tests for
python2.6.

Also imports patch_tox_venv.py. This is a cutdown version of what would
happen in run_tests.sh but for tox environments which is how jenkins
runs tests now.

Change-Id: I369c3e464dfbe3a754f90db58785e97ac87b36c0

commit_message:
Require keystone-user/-group for pki_setup

If pki_setup is run as root, require the keystone-user
and keystone-group parameter to be set, to enforce
the proper permissions to be created on the files.

This follows a suggestion in the Bugreport.

Fixes LP Bug #1031372

Change-Id: I00d9e0499d16716af3267914b6b78841f1ad1e0f

commit_message:
Update Chef dependency to Chef 11

Also add dependency on json <= 1.7.7, required by Chef 11.

Resolves problem: Bundler could not find compatible versions for gem
"json" (required for chef and berkshelf).

Partial fix for bug #1183540

Change-Id: I422eb3423ab2ac9234c7e19707909ff7423f5be9

Made changes to the test code. XML attributes are strings so made changes in code to handle that.

Fixes Bug #1165077

Change-Id: I6272c4cf9d22a6090f41b41a66e52506068532cc
'}]
commit_message:
Integer Flavor Ids

Changed the flavor id type in the instances schema to an Integer in a patch.
Made changes to the test code. XML attributes are strings so made changes in code to handle that.

Fixes Bug #1165077

Change-Id: I6272c4cf9d22a6090f41b41a66e52506068532cc

Add missing tests for iscsi_* methods

There was no tests in test_db_api for iscsi_*
methods.

Bug 1187367 found.

blueprint db-api-tests

commit_message:
Keypair API test cleanup

This is a cleanup in preparation for adding more
test coverage around keypairs. This patch does the
following:

* Moves keypair tests into their own file

* Breaks tests for methods into logically separate
  classes

* Shares key name validation and quota checking
  tests between `create` and `import_key`

* As part of above, add missing tests for
  `import_key` that were present for
  `create`

Change-Id: I8d8fdf9a1f9f11e1015ebbdfde1c8e77f5f421a8

commit_message:
Add missing .debs required by Debian

dnsmasq-utils is available on all Debian-based supported distros.

Debian Wheezy and Jessie need qemu to be installed in order for the resulting
OpenStack environment to be fully functional.

Change-Id: I910968f60ca1ed5c300a1fa599fb480d65591145

commit_message:
Set variables in rsyslog.conf to disable rate-limiting.

Per Bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ci/+bug/1024487, this will
modify the rate-limiting setting for rsyslog.conf.  If rate-limiting is
being used the addition will set it to 0 otherwise the addition will
add the variables to the configuration file and set them to 0.

Implements: Variables "$SystemLogRateLimitBurst 0", and
"$SystemLogRateLimitInterval 0" in "/etc/rsyslog.conf". These changes
are persuent to what has been outlined in the rsyslog docs as found
here : http://www.rsyslog.com/tag/SystemLogRateLimitInterval/

Updated commit implements changes in code and placement post code
review. Recent change implements the "SystemLogRateLimitBurst" in first
if statement, which was "SystemLogRateLimitInterval" and wrong.

Fixes: Bug 1024487
Change-Id: I2637889cbe9e5e87bbfc0f1bb5047abae34d953c

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/31155/2/check/gate-python-heatclient-pep8/122 : SUCCESS in 47s

- http://logs.openstack.org/31155/2/check/dev-python-heatclient-coverage/71 : FAILURE in 7s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-06-01 14:29:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This is interesting. I had thought environments would be something that was resolved in the engine, not the client. So one would do something like:

heat environment-create production production.yaml
heat environment-create dev dev.yaml

I understand that sometimes you want to talk to completely different clouds. One long term goal seems to be to have one heat engine able to talk to many clouds for one stack as well, so it would seem to me that having environments in the engine makes more sense.

For directing heatclient at a different cloud, we already have OS_AUTH_URL, OS_USERNAME, etc. etc. The implementation I see above is mostly redundant with that.'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-04 22:34:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Clint, that concept is not in conflict with what I have posted. I am trying to start simple and work to the complex if needed.'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-04 22:38:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

As far as directing at different clouds goes, many current public clouds do not have an installed heat so the creds you need to talk to heat are different to the ones that heat needs to talk to the public cloud. This puts in place a mechanism to do that.'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-06-05 04:35:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-07 00:15:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-07 00:15:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

commit_message:
Add support for environment files

env.yaml:
"
parameters:
 KeyName: heat_key
"
heat stack-create foo -e env.yaml -P "<more params here>" -f bla.yaml

blueprint environments
Change-Id: If40d4b6396cc69452bb1e13654ca8bb3d61e24fb

commit_message:
Add API mac learning extension for NVP

This commit adds an API extension for NVP where the
NVP supported mac learning feature can be switched
on/off for a specific port. The attribute can be
True or False or omitted altogether.

Implements blueprint nvp-mac-learning-extension

Change-Id: I9173c7dfe0cf4a9ee7b0605722ce7fa01708f5ba

commit_message:
Update Chef dependency to Chef 11

Also add dependency on json <= 1.7.7, required by Chef 11.

Resolves problem: Bundler could not find compatible versions for gem
"json" (required for chef and berkshelf).

Partial fix for bug #1183540

Change-Id: Ia10a0256b782eafe70363e737f4f79ce2bb8be82

commit_message:
Update Chef dependency to Chef 11

Also add dependency on json <= 1.7.7, required by Chef 11.

Resolves problem: Bundler could not find compatible versions for gem
"json" (required for chef and berkshelf).

Partial fix for bug #1183540

Change-Id: Ibf835df3bb8ee06c806ea523110d381b94672944

Partial fix for bug #1183540

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-06 01:24:55.000000000', 'message': "Use nova bindir of /usr/bin on Fedora

Fedora (and RHEL) like to install things in /usr/bin, e.g.

 01:30:42 Creating /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nova.egg-link (link to .)
 01:30:42 Adding nova 2013.2.a1031.gfc5137d to easy-install.pth file
 01:30:42 Installing nova-dhcpbridge script to /usr/bin
 ...

The default nova/paths.py defaults to /usr/local/... which causes
quite a few errors when stressing various parts of nova and tools
aren't found.

Change-Id: Iaa93af96ddfb4deb6d16ea1dcac25ae6ed1e317d
"}]
commit_message:
Use nova bindir of /usr/bin on Fedora

Fedora (and RHEL) like to install things in /usr/bin, e.g.

 01:30:42 Creating /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nova.egg-link (link to .)
 01:30:42 Adding nova 2013.2.a1031.gfc5137d to easy-install.pth file
 01:30:42 Installing nova-dhcpbridge script to /usr/bin
 ...

The default nova/paths.py defaults to /usr/local/... which causes
quite a few errors when stressing various parts of nova and tools
aren't found.

Change-Id: Iaa93af96ddfb4deb6d16ea1dcac25ae6ed1e317d

[{'created': '2013-06-05 22:34:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add Fake virt driver support

nova fake virt driver can be used to simulate running arbitrarily large
number of VMs.  When the fake virt driver is selected, all other arbitrary
limits are disabled (quotas, scheduler limitations) as well. The fake
virt driver can be selected by adding the following line to your localrc

      VIRT_DRIVER=fake

This setting can be used to do simulated large scale (as defined by
number of VMs) testing (such as boot 500 VMs at once) inside a single
devstack instance.

Change-Id: I000c3cba107cd91bef11c4d5325e1ce7308faa6c

This setting can be used to do simulated large scale (as defined by

Change-Id: I000c3cba107cd91bef11c4d5325e1ce7308faa6c

commit_message:
Add Fake virt driver support

nova fake virt driver can be used to simulate running arbitrarily large
number of VMs.  When the fake virt driver is selected, all other arbitrary
limits are disabled (quotas, scheduler limitations) as well. The fake
virt driver can be selected by adding the following line to your localrc

      VIRT_DRIVER=fake

This setting can be used to do simulated large scale (as defined by
number of VMs) testing (such as boot 500 VMs at once) inside a single
devstack instance.

Change-Id: I000c3cba107cd91bef11c4d5325e1ce7308faa6c

This patch leverages the third-party mechanism provided by DevStack
to customize the configuration of DevStack instances when working
with the Quantum NVP plugin. This is useful in dev/test scenarios,
where connectivity between the DevStack VM and the NVP Gateway is
required.

Supports blueprint nvp-third-party-support

Change-Id: I3f5afa5de1219f491e37c8b9b28370855d6b017c
'}]
commit_message:
Add third-party support for Quantum NVP plugin

This patch leverages the third-party mechanism provided by DevStack
to customize the configuration of DevStack instances when working
with the Quantum NVP plugin. This is useful in dev/test scenarios,
where connectivity between the DevStack VM and the NVP Gateway is
required.

Supports blueprint nvp-third-party-support

Change-Id: I3f5afa5de1219f491e37c8b9b28370855d6b017c

commit_message:
Add nova configuration reference tables

This is the first attempt at automatically generated configuration
tables being added to documentation.
blueprint autogenerate-config-tables
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Blueprint-autogenerate-config-tables

Work is being conducted out-of-repo at :

https://github.com/fifieldt/autogenerate-config-docs

Nova has existing tables, which are out of date for Grizzly.

Patchset 2:

Based on positive feedback, patchset 2 links in the tables to the
Compute Administration Guide, expanding its configuration reference,
adding config option sections to areas that lacked them and
removing old tables.

Patchset 3/4 just updates the author's email address.

Cherry-picked from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28904/

Change-Id: I2c400fa511df5c878c5b640085a6e5286b1dd318

commit_message:
Corrected to support Chef 11

Need to Array.new vs simply casting to Array.  Also, tests would
not pass with the recent grub/lxc work.  Was hoping to stub
`#set_boot_kernel_and_trigger_reboot` but found that to be
difficult.  Ended up stubbing the result of File.open.  This
section needs better testing.
  Failure/Error: @chef_run.converge "openstack-compute::libvirt"
  Errno::ENOENT:
   No such file or directory - /boot/grub/menu.lst
  # ./.cookbooks/openstack-compute/recipes/libvirt.rb:34:in `initialize'
  # ./.cookbooks/openstack-compute/recipes/libvirt.rb:34:in `open'
  # ./.cookbooks/openstack-compute/recipes/libvirt.rb:34:in `set_boot_kernel_and_trigger_reboot'
  # ./.cookbooks/openstack-compute/recipes/libvirt.rb:79:in `from_file'
  # ./.cookbooks/openstack-compute/spec/libvirt-opensuse_spec.rb:10:in `block (3 levels) in <top (required)>'

Change-Id: Ie97309ff5e1bf30a02714597fe29c1d0df1b1c23

commit_message:
Using correct volume driver paths

  cinder.volume.X instead of cinder.volume.drivers.X results in a
  deprecation warning in the cinder-volume log.

  https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/etc/cinder/cinder.conf.sample#L1352-L1353

Change-Id: Ica4ff79b3ccc35a9d3ff64bdc0bb89a94e7ead1f

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-06 20:53:00.000000000', 'message': 'Treat directory objects as not found

Make StaticWeb search for an index file rather than returning a 0-byte
object.

Add new StaticWeb header to identify a directory marker object:
X-Container-Meta-Web-Directory-Type (default to application/directory)
so user can specify the content type for directory marker objects.
This required requesting the container headers earlier in the code and
clearing the value of _error for non-404 errors.

Add unit tests for directory object scenarios.
Fix end tags in an unrelated HTML block.

Bug 1178817

DocImpact

Change-Id: I561f00c099feaa82fd658f5050bd90c76717da24

Updates

Change-Id: I3021ab62e8469f1c3eb0ab3f70f1bcd8e7e5476f
'}]
commit_message:
Treat directory objects as not found

Make StaticWeb search for an index file rather than returning a 0-byte
object.

Add new StaticWeb header to identify a directory marker object:
X-Container-Meta-Web-Directory-Type (default to application/directory)
so user can specify the content type for directory marker objects.
This required requesting the container headers earlier in the code and
clearing the value of _error for non-404 errors.

Add unit tests for directory object scenarios.
Fix end tags in an unrelated HTML block.

Bug 1178817

DocImpact

Change-Id: I561f00c099feaa82fd658f5050bd90c76717da24

Updates

Change-Id: I3021ab62e8469f1c3eb0ab3f70f1bcd8e7e5476f

commit_message:
Added test - conditional object download

Uses 'If-None-Match' header, should download object only if the local copy is
different.

commit_message:
Add python-cinderclient to requirements.txt

The scenario tests manager has an import for cinderclient, however
python-cinderclient was not listed as a requirement. This corrects
the oversight by adding python-cinderclient to requirements.txt.

Change-Id: I92cc4144cc2392391ee80a4f55783acd0f70c483

commit_message:
Fixes the multi-backend skip bug and the cleanup steps

The multi-backend test class and the tests within should now be
skipped correctly also when running on python 2.6. Also fixes
a cleanup problem occurring in case of error in setUpClass and
speed things up by not creating the 2nd volume/type if backends
have the same name (in which case only part of the tests can be
executed).

Change-Id: Ibeb961ea000bb1d1034f857a64552c7aa75ed4d5
Fixes: bug #1177608

commit_message:
Multi-server handling in base.py

Moving the logic to handle a list of servers
returned by the create from test_multi_create
into compute/base.py, including test_multiple_create.

Fixes bug #1180823

Change-Id: I2f3ecb44f8a26c4fc912accba2c44707b97ee1e7

[{'created': '2013-06-05 19:19:37.000000000', 'message': 'Fix tests for python 2.6

Since python 2.6 is supported in openstack we need to
alter the format messages and the usage of functions
that exist in the 2.7 unittest by including unittest2
and using that instead.

Change-Id: I31c78d1f771603a6ad15ada50507cada0c5e331b
'}]
commit_message:
Fix tests for python 2.6

Since python 2.6 is supported in openstack we need to
alter the format messages and the usage of functions
that exist in the 2.7 unittest by including unittest2
and using that instead.

Change-Id: I31c78d1f771603a6ad15ada50507cada0c5e331b

subject: Add basic lazy gettext implementation
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 5371, 'name': 'Mathew Odden', 'email': 'locke105@gmail.com', 'username': 'locke105'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}, {'_account_id': 6159, 'name': 'Flavio Percoco Premoli', 'email': 'fpercoco@redhat.com', 'username': 'flaper87'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-04-16 15:59:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-04-21 15:59:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Matthew, can you please add some tests?'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-04-21 15:59:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-04-22 14:04:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

We discussed this a little at the summit during this session : https://etherpad.openstack.org/havana-oslo-i18n-strategy

The implementation looks quite scarey and complicated, but TranslationProxy from sphinx does a similar thing AFAICT: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/src/7c437d4e4f10b14889585d5b41d5d9c634ea1503/sphinx/locale/__init__.py?at=default

Also, feel free to just add this to gettextutils

Marking with -1 for now. I'm happy to re-review if you can explain why it needs to be more complicated than the sphinx code though

Oh, also - for new APIs, I'd really like to see a WIP review showing how the new API would be used in one of the services - e.g. start with something relatively easy like keystone

Thanks for the patch!"}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-04-22 23:00:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@dims, I have tests that I am planning to upload when I get a chance. I had to throw together the current patch on short notice for the Summit discussion.

@markmc, unfortunately I became aware of the sphinx code after I began the work on the Message class. The sphinx proxy does a cleaner job of delaying the translation, but unfortunately once the '%' operator is used to inject parameter values into the object, it becomes just a regular string again. We lose information about the original string (gettext msgid) and also the extra information injected in from the '%' operation. This is what the Message class is supposed to overcome, so that later, we can find the msgid, do a translation to some locale, and then inject the parameters. Also, I didn't see any way of changing the locale the TranslationProxy gets translated to while in-flight.

I can definitely see a lot of ways the Message class can still be improved though.

By example for the API usage, I'm assuming you mean how would a message going out in a response from the REST API be translated using this? There is a really old change in Nova for such a case here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20949/

Thanks for the comments. I'll be working on getting the tests pulled in for the next patchset."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-04-30 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-04-30 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-07 12:11:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

To put my feedback re: sphinx in another way - I just can't see a gettext helper as complicated as this getting merged right off the bat

The use case I'm most interested in right now that this code could be useful for is translating strings in a REST API response according to the locale specified in the request

Perhaps for such strings we can have an object that more explicitly represents an un-interpolated and untranslated strings, along with its interpolation args and has a method for turning it into a string according to a given locale

We don't need to delay the translation of every string to each the requirements for the REST API, so I'm really in favour of something more simple and explicit for that use case as an initial baby step"}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-05-08 00:04:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

markmc, Ok I see what you mean now. I actually just got a chance to start re-visiting this and I finished getting my test cases imported from my previous prototyping.

I am working on pulling in a lot of the sphinx techniques and merging them with the existing code to remember the un-interpolated arguments and original string in attributes. Locale translation should be pretty easy after that.'}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-05-09 18:42:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Restored'}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-05-09 18:43:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-09 18:46:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-20 11:57:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: (24 inline comments)

I think this is making decent progress

My overall comment is that we should fallback to the default UserString implementation as much as possible. I think the fundamental thing we're trying to do with the specialized implementation is creating new objects e.g.

    def __mul__(self, n):
        return self.__class__(self.data*n)

I'm thinking we want something like this:

 class MyString(UserString):

     def __init__(self, msg, domain=None):
         self.data = msg

         if domain is not None:
             self._domain = domain
             self.__class__ = type(self.__class__.__name__,
                                   (self.__class__, ),
                                   dict(DOMAIN=domain))
         else:
             self._domain = getattr(self, 'DOMAIN', None)

 s = MyString('foo', 'domain')
 tens = s * 10"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-20 13:02:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-20 13:05:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Oh, I forgot to say something else ...

One thing that could happen here is that the code gets merged into oslo-incubator, but no projects end up using it for whatever reason ... in that case, we'd end up removing again

The point is that getting this code merged is only the starting point - there's a lot of work ahead to get projects to use it"}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-05-21 23:52:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: (26 inline comments)

Lots and lots of fixes. Still need to address the localedir issue, but I'm going to push what I have at the moment since there is a lot that has changed."}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-05-21 23:57:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 23:59:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

Also, if we want to install lazy gettext as the default gettext function, we should add gettextutils.install_lazy() or something"}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-06-06 18:48:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Add basic lazy gettext implementation

This is the first part of an implementation towards
a deferred localization functionality in OpenStack.
This change adds a Message class for encapsulating a
translatable message and its relevant data, as well
as an example LogHandler of how such a class can be
used in the logging context.

bp delayed-message-translation

Change-Id: I8485a346d32925327ea9185e0da3822e4e19c2f5

commit_message:
python3: Remove mox support from oslo.config.

Mox is not python3 compliant so remove it in
favor of fixtures.

Change-Id: I381b3ba0434d7f1261c898992a7b7974c64b1fea
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Removed invalid skipped tests

Swift tempauth doesn't support publicly writable containers.

From http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/misc.html
"Also, .r designations aren’t allowed in headers whose names include the word
‘write’."

Change-Id: Iaf23cfe2ff4682c0b42d89e9928dc37f8bdbc26b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-06 14:36:29.000000000', 'message': "TestServerAdvancedOps server leaking

When added the testresources added as base class the resource variable usage
changed, and it renamed to os_resources in the other places.

TestServerAdvancedOps still want to use the old variable,
 however the base class has proper tearDownClass method.

Let the TestServerAdvancedOps to use the base class's tearDownClass.

Fixes Bug 1157306

Change-Id: I9bc1c90d526865cafbc6fbf71172aae10e95cb7d
"}]
commit_message:
TestServerAdvancedOps server leaking

When added the testresources added as base class the resource variable usage
changed, and it renamed to os_resources in the other places.

TestServerAdvancedOps still want to use the old variable,
 however the base class has proper tearDownClass method.

Let the TestServerAdvancedOps to use the base class's tearDownClass.

Fixes Bug 1157306

Change-Id: I9bc1c90d526865cafbc6fbf71172aae10e95cb7d

commit_message:
Add x-compute-request-id header when no response body

The x-compute-request-id header was only being added for requests which
generated a response body, like an index or show.  This adds it to
requests which generate no response body, like create/update/delete, or
actions on servers like resize.

Bug 1183712

Change-Id: Ia0e9d75e4b84280caab060fae58036ed818e00c3

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-06 12:32:46.000000000', 'message': "Alphabetize v3 API extension entry point list

Alphabetize the v3 API extension point list in setup.cfg. With lots
of extensions being ported to V3 and an entry needed in setup.cfg for
each one and multiple people working on the ports if we always just
add an entry to the end of the list we are going to get a lot of merge
conflicts. To minimise the number of conflicts we'll try keeping the
list in alphabetical order and the number of conflicts should drop
as the list gets longer.

Change-Id: I386ec9bdb99660861d80f47923855e73f474a15f
"}]
commit_message:
Alphabetize v3 API extension entry point list

Alphabetize the v3 API extension point list in setup.cfg. With lots
of extensions being ported to V3 and an entry needed in setup.cfg for
each one and multiple people working on the ports if we always just
add an entry to the end of the list we are going to get a lot of merge
conflicts. To minimise the number of conflicts we'll try keeping the
list in alphabetical order and the number of conflicts should drop
as the list gets longer.

Change-Id: I386ec9bdb99660861d80f47923855e73f474a15f

commit_message:
Removed unused netapp driver attribute

This is a left over attribute from when we were backporting netapp patches
to our folsom installation. Since we've removed the patches, we don't need
this attribute anymore.

Change-Id: Ib34cdfb7f36d379ec3f0c8b9c08a6b6271ece9f3

- http://logs.openstack.org/31908/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/28031 : SUCCESS in 18m 14s
- http://logs.openstack.org/31908/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/8298 : SUCCESS in 13m 49s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2013-06-06 17:22:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So what this actually does is make it so that when you run 'tox' it tries to run 2.6, 2.7, 3.3, and pep8 tests.  AFAIK, that will only work if you're on Debian.

I think the default tox command should run the most common tests that work for the most number of developers.  I'd recommend just setting it to "pep8, py27", and let Jenkins take care of the rest of the variants.

(Adding 'py33' to this list is not required in order for 'tox -e py33' to work.)'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-06 17:29:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

I didn't know that you could just do 'tox -e py33' to work"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-06 02:36:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add python3.3 support to tox.ini

As this is a requirement for making any project py33 compatible, lets add
a py33 tox environment for testing

Change-Id: Ie86e3bee2f217d24286e76df9740248a760305f8
'}]
commit_message:
Add python3.3 support to tox.ini

As this is a requirement for making any project py33 compatible, lets add
a py33 tox environment for testing

Change-Id: Ie86e3bee2f217d24286e76df9740248a760305f8

commit_message:
Adding missing tests to the blackbox group.

- This will make the tests to be run in live-mode
- Adding quota tests
- Adding security group tests
- Adding backup tests

Fixes bug # 1187133

Change-Id: I67bfe0038d47ce96e16012651c2798d3457701a1

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-28 20:57:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think this is fine, however, if it's using AWS native structures instead of OpenStack Native, it needs to live in thirdparty"}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-05-28 21:55:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

This test is not validating compatibility with any third party API - AWS doesn't support YAML syntax templates.

We'll be incrementally replacing things that refer to AWS bit by bit throughout this cycle with OpenStack native alternatives, some examples being:
- blueprints to implement native resource types (alternatives to Type: AWS::EC2::...)
- using keystone Trusts to perform authenticated operations from nova servers (replaces AWS::IAM::AccessKey)
- alternative in-instance tools to replace cfn-init, cfn-signal, cfn-hup which use the native REST API.

We are committed to this process, but it is incremental. I think this test belongs here now, because when we're done it will obviously belong here."}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-05-28 22:41:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

The yaml templates are OpenStack specific.  Even though the JSON is similar in nature to AWS, we support many features (such as instance SchedulerHints) which AWS does not support.  Heat has pretty much become non-aws specific in trunk, and this will further occur with the changes to the templating language to appear in either one of these reviews:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28598/

or

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/27934/

We would prefer tempest gating before we get to the point of actually implementing the code which processes those templates, although some work is underway in:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30439/

This is an incremental process which will take time in the Havana dev cycle to flesh out.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-05-31 21:12:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-05 20:43:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I agree that heat adds a grey area here with the fact that the API is Heat native, but the resource names are borrowed from a thirdparty.

API is very much intended to be an osnative space, where all tests could be run by someone that wanted to purge any thirdparty references out of them.

I'll +2 for now given the h2 blueprint to make os native resource names. Please file a tempest bug targeted for h2 to get this switched over."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-05 21:36:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Thanks Sean, I've filed this https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1187942"}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-06-06 05:19:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-06-06 14:56:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-06 14:56:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-06 16:39:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Heat test to launch a heat-cfntools based instance.

It only runs if config heat_available is true and an
image_ref is specified.

Blueprint: add-basic-heat-tests

commit_message:
Fixes a problem occurring if setUpClass faced errors during image creation

This fixes an error where cls.delete_image was asked to delete a non
existing image due to possible errors raising in setUpClass

Change-Id: Ibbf7970b59658088b7eff2357cf3cf674a52b268
Fixes: bug 1172704

commit_message:
./run_tests.sh -d nova.tests.conductor.test_conductor raising exception

When running the runn_tests.sh with the above arguments the test
framework was trying to override a configuration option that wasn't
imported.

Fixes: bug 1188120

Change-Id: I7cb23e2785c66a7478be303cb2daa2c98865965b

commit_message:
Added common code into fileutils and strutils.

This methods are present in nova, cinder and also needed by ironic package.

openstack.common.strutils => nova.utils <=> cinder.utils
    to_bytes(text, default=0)

openstack.common.fileutils => nova.utils <=> cinder.utils <=> nova/virt/libvirt/utils.py
    file_open(*args, **kwargs)

Change-Id: Ia65499b77eb551c0ffb6d48767b899435469bfb6
Implements: blueprint image-tools

commit_message:
Import osapi_v3/enabled option in nova/test

Since `nova/api/openstack` may not have been imported by the time we use this
option in `nova/test`, we need to explicitly import it at the top of the file.

Fixes bug 1187847

Change-Id: Ibc9f3466d3baaf47d44bda2fc22247a494809909

commit_message:
Add common code for fileutils.

This code is present in nova, cinder and also needed by ironic package.
* delete_if_exists
* remove_path_on_error

Also added some tests.

openstack/common/fileutils.py => nova.common.utils <=> cinder.common.utils

Change-Id: Id5001db161bb8e7dfb20d1b2cc2033e886cda32f
Implements: blueprint image-tools

commit_message:
WIP support for auditing events in standardized formats

sample proof of concept code for audit events bp.
will be refined to support:
audit notifier wrapper
CADF data validator/formatter

blueprint: support-standard-audit-formats

Change-Id: If2736f0a1c58e5a90130dd1ea6c8152855b39170

commit_message:
Port base object from Nova.

Forked from Nova ed6099d77ed1ee4a2c8c8b135d6ac18f70d48625 and
pulled 'deleted' attribute from Nova 15fe833f5fb8d847a21061d802d194a74cf3d0ad.

Resolved dependencies and renamed all "Nova-" to "Ironic-"
The patch implements: blueprint db-objects

Change-Id: Id51599af88fe84451b3e746a9e51bd760d61da84

Hi James,

This patch looks pretty good! I've made some notes inline about what set of policy restrictions we need to have.

It might also make sense to add some tests to glance/tests/unit/test_policy.py, similar to TestImagePolicy.

Thanks for driving this change. The glance team will talk about this blueprint tomorrow at our meeting (20:00 UTC in #openstack-meeting-alt). You are (of course!) welcome to attend, though I don't expect a lot of resistance to approving the blueprint.

Sorry I took so long to get around to reviewing it!"}, {'account_id': 6662, 'date': '2013-05-30 17:16:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Add policies for membership APIs

Added following policies for membership APIs:

v1: 'get_members', 'delete_member' and 'modify_member'.

v2: 'new_member', 'add_member', 'get_member', 'modify_member',
'get_members' and 'delete_member'.

Implements blueprint membership-policy

Change-Id: Ia0cdc589eea691677d1321cd8813efa820bfdc55

'}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2013-05-03 16:11:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Thank you for your contribution.  This will be a nice improvement when finished.

However, this implementation is incomplete.  tenants_list() is called several places to correlate data from different sources.  A truncated list will not work for that type of operation.  There needs to be a way to request the full list.  The only place a truncated list is actually desired is in the project index views.  So a parameter to tenants_list() specifying whether pagination is desired is required.

Also, unit tests that exercise the pagination in both the paginated and non-paginated use cases need to be added to openstack_dashboard/test/api_tests/keystone_tests.py"}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2013-05-04 01:25:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2013-05-04 02:09:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2013-05-04 02:18:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-04 03:03:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2013-05-21 08:50:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: (1 inline comment)

V3 hasn't actually exposed paging to the API yet. it just returns all collections and null previos/next links as:

  "links": {
      "previous": null,
      "self": url,
      "next": null,
  }

So, this patch is just support v2 pagination yet.'}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:51:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

My only concern is that it seems odd to close a bug that fixes pagination and not support the now default keystone API version.  That said...  Since you've registered the blueprint and the v3 API support in keystone is incomplete, I renamed the bug title to reflect that it is only a v2 fix.  

Thanks for sticking with this."}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2013-05-28 10:37:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

the current behaviour is broken and every fix is appreciated! I'd love to see a complete fix (for v2 and v3) to me merged rather sooner than later. Still I think, customers can't understand this regression when switching from keystone v2 to v3."}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2013-05-28 21:55:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20:

The problem is that the client and keystone don't support pagination in v3 yet for either the server or the client, see: https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-keystoneclient/+bug/1009023"}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2013-05-30 22:15:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2013-05-30 22:16:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script.'}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2013-05-30 22:19:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

Matthias, the problem is that keystone doesn't support pagination in v3 yet for either the server or the client, see: https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-keystoneclient/+bug/1009023  The best we can do is add v2.0 support.  The regression is not in Horizon."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 23:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Works for me

Matthias: I think the implementation for pagination support should be done incrementally. Zhenguo: I meant setting a pagination_param value in TenantsTable meta (horizon/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/projects/tables.py). It doesn't affect the functionality but it does help someone else reading TenantsTable class to identify that the table supports pagination even without digging into the code further. 

Sample here: https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/images_and_snapshots/images/tables.py#L221"}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2013-06-04 06:27:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

commit_message:
Adding pagination to the tenant views

Modifying the api.keystone.tenants_list() method by setting
limit/marker parameters to handle pagination.

Change-Id: Ice67a6112ed8b90095e9c9991bee3e715c22ec01
Fixes: bug #904003

commit_message:
python3: Introduce py33 to tox.ini

Introduce py33 to tox.ini to make testing with
python3 easier.

Change-Id: If979800c5c337996bfdfa5bc99d03ad945192816
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2013-05-03 18:16:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

A few things:

1. Rather than write all of these rules into a giant if-else in the form, I'd rather see this list be defined in a configurable/customizable fashion. One idea would be to put them in the settings file in a dictionary with the keys being the "name" of the rule (what goes into the dropdown menu) and the values being a dict or tuple containing the values for the fields. That way an administrator could change these rules in the conf if they use different port mappings or want to add/remove options.

2. If you select a different rule here you still end up with blank fields for the port mappings. Those fields need to either have the default values filled or otherwise be hidden.

3. These don't address traffic sources... that's probably intentional, but when I see "allow all <protocol>" I assume that'll apply to the source as well.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2013-05-08 03:49:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-08 04:34:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Add security group rule templates

Add a variety of common port mappings in a dropdown to help
users add security rules.

Change-Id: If7422c21eae56580f0fc2403cb08ba25655a73a4
Implements: blueprint security-group-rule-templates

commit_message:
node_availability_zone deprecated

Updated node_availability_zone to default_availability_zone, as it has been
renamed.
This change was introduced in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18675/

The docs have been updated according to

https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+bug/1107419

Change-Id: I8974d96fc34a4a7e8cf6b51468395dc59a80de2c

[{'created': '2013-06-06 13:30:37.000000000', 'message': 'Adding hardware-agent

    This adds basic monitoring for physical devices. The structure is similar to the compute-agent.
    The agent is designed for easy extending with other inspectors.
    The hardware-agent is configurable over the hardware-agent.conf as well as over the ceilometer.conf

    Change-Id: I0fc28bc148411b390bb8b3ffcb15b7951ee20e06
    Implements: blueprint monitoring-physical-devices

Change-Id: I0f3b9aecd60c1c54cd9f0fb4e7a75706d26f5aa6
'}]
commit_message:
Adding hardware-agent

    This adds basic monitoring for physical devices. The structure is similar to the compute-agent.
    The agent is designed for easy extending with other inspectors.
    The hardware-agent is configurable over the hardware-agent.conf as well as over the ceilometer.conf

    Change-Id: I0fc28bc148411b390bb8b3ffcb15b7951ee20e06
    Implements: blueprint monitoring-physical-devices

Change-Id: I0f3b9aecd60c1c54cd9f0fb4e7a75706d26f5aa6

commit_message:
Add find() method to CrudManager

Add a find() methods to CrudManager to maintain compatability
with existing CLI lookups using utils.find_resource().

Change-Id: Ia9b38b975bb88fb361f3471b66f98c7e81bbc6de

commit_message:
Make autoscale not dependent on loadbalancer impl.

Autoscale was calling reload on a resource, which is not part of the
resource interface. Autoscale has been modified to use update.

Change-Id: Ifb17c9def7e560d96e26308db67b4ee3f93a2b9f

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names.

Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Fixes: bug #1179008
Change-Id: I033876ec304fea97c66365c16bcf0cccaa1d810e

[{'created': '2013-06-05 16:05:08.000000000', 'message': "Fix config help order to be alphabetical

Currently The output of --help is in random order. The only way using public
argparse api to control the order of display of --help is to add the arguments
in the sorted order. So added a caching mechanism to collect all the calls
to add_argument and ensure they are sorted before calling argparse's
add_argument. The only other choice if anyone is interested is documented
here which uses the non-public API

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12268602/sort-argparse-help-alphabetically

Fixes LP# 1185959

Change-Id: I5f934c85fd516e2d87b3ece40142f16c898b04ce

commit_message:
Fix config help order to be alphabetical

Currently The output of --help is in random order. The only way using public
argparse api to control the order of display of --help is to add the arguments
in the sorted order. So added a caching mechanism to collect all the calls
to add_argument and ensure they are sorted before calling argparse's
add_argument. The only other choice if anyone is interested is documented
here which uses the non-public API

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12268602/sort-argparse-help-alphabetically

Fixes LP# 1185959

Change-Id: I5f934c85fd516e2d87b3ece40142f16c898b04ce

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 14:15:23.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-31 21:38:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I was hoping to not add new checks until we get better testing in place.  So we could release a 0.5.5 version of hacking, with some general bug fixes but without any new rules, which would force us to releases version 0.6.

Currently in the assorted test-requires we say the version must be lower then 0.6, allowing us to release bug fixes without adding new rules that would break the gate.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-06 10:01:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Is there some way we can have new tests off by default?'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-06 11:21:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Off by default isn't going to help, because then tox would become this giant white list for projects, instead of a decreasing black list."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-06 11:45:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Fundamentally, projects need to opt in to new checks

We can do that by batching them up - add a whole bunch of off-by-default checks in the 0.5.x series, then enable all the off-by-default checks in 0.6.0

Projects can opt in incrementally by selectively enabling the off-by-default while still using 0.5.x or they can wait until 0.6.0 is released and enable using 0.6.0 and all the new checks in one go'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-06 11:55:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

right, fair. The current model is just that no new checks are turned on until the version bump (i.e. 0.5 -> 0.6). But having a way that we could land checks that we could optionally turn on in a stable series (0.5.5) would have value.

A lot of this just comes back to whether hacking needs stable branches (which was an IRC conversation the other day). The general concensus was no, we are just at an early stage where some critical bugs need to land and get out to everyone before new checks come in.

Maybe we should take this to the mailing list instead of a closed review that only you and I are probably reading. :)'}]

commit_message:
add check that python files have Apache 2.0 license stanza

I just had to -1 a proposed commit to Tempest which was missing
this, and found that 4 files in our tree didn't have it. We should
enforce that all the python files have this header when they are
in tree.

Skip files < 10 lines, which is needed for empty file support, and
to not bail on our Okay doctests.

Updated to include a check for an Apache looking LICENSE file as a
precondition.

Change-Id: Id3f9b6099301f998ce3185e9fd0ed6907e6e71f0

commit_message:
Handle instance directories correctly for migrates.

In Grizzly we changed how we name instance directories. Unfortunately
the decision as to what directory name to use is based on whether
there is a pre-existing directory on the compute node with the old
name.

In the case of live migration, that doesn't work because we have
libvirt copy the directory across for us. So, we need to pass
around the directory name in the migration request. This is better
anyway, as it means that ops types don't need to handle an instance
directory magically renaming itself at some point.

Resolves bug 1175286.

Change-Id: Ib102e644a8742726fa2049303354d466b8109e0b

Change-Id: I15c2faa64f5695bc7fb490becb33b1fdf662028a

commit_message:
Install qemu-utils explicitly.

In Ubuntu 13.04 qemu-utils is not in the same dependency chain, but is
needed by nova-compute for image manipulation.

Change-Id: I15c2faa64f5695bc7fb490becb33b1fdf662028a

'}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2013-06-03 09:25:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I was looking for a command to check if the device is still valid. I tried "fdisk -l". If the connection is good, it returns the infomation about the device. If the network is physically disconnected, it returns empty.

If there is better command to do something equivalent, it is ideal to replace it.

I think "hdparm -t <dev>" may be better and I will give a try. Any comments?'}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2013-06-06 07:17:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I tested with the command sudo hdparm -t <dev>. If the device is available, the output will be something like Timing buffered disk reads:  34 MB in  3.10 seconds =  10.95 MB/sec, indicating the device read speed. Otherwise, the output will give Timing buffered disk reads: read() failed: Input/output error to show the device is not connected. I think hdparm -t can be used for the read test of the device.
If the read test fails, we can safely say the device is not available.'}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2013-06-06 09:45:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add the iscsi device check and exception processing.

Before executing the command "qemu-img convert", check if the iSCSI device is
still available via the command "fdisk -l". "fdisk -l" will give no output
about the device, if the device is unavailable. If it is unavailable, there is
no need to download the image & "qemu-img convert" and an exception
VolumeDeviceUnavailable will be raised.

Fixed Bug1169290.

Change-Id: Icc34c38403fd7f55bf423abf27a2516be0692689
