Change-Id: I9f7072dcbbb4609fa573501a9f2b55e8849b790a
"}, {'created': '2013-05-21 15:32:09.000000000', 'message': "Unified logging strategy from oslo-incubator

This commit introduces a unified logging strategy from oslo-incubator in
an attempt to standardize logging in Keystone similar to other OpenStack
projects (Nova, Quantum, etc.). This commit keeps
keystone/common/config.py as a wrapper to
keystone/openstack/common/log.py
but instead of carrying out logging setup in config.py it calls into
setup() within log.py.

This change contains changes from oslo-incubator to existing files in
Keystone, in which case those files were sync'd. Pulling in changes from
oslo-incubator requires dependencies from within oslo-incubator and
explains pulling in other modules outside of log.py. These other modules
are going to be used with notification work (specifically notifier/ and
rpc/ modules).

blueprint unified-logging-in-keystone

Change-Id: I9f7072dcbbb4609fa573501a9f2b55e8849b790a
"}, {'created': '2013-05-21 20:09:38.000000000', 'message': "Unified logging strategy from oslo-incubator

This commit introduces a unified logging strategy from oslo-incubator in
an attempt to standardize logging in Keystone similar to other OpenStack
projects (Nova, Quantum, etc.). This commit keeps
keystone/common/config.py as a wrapper to
keystone/openstack/common/log.py
but instead of carrying out logging setup in config.py it calls into
setup() within log.py.

This change contains changes from oslo-incubator to existing files in
Keystone, in which case those files were sync'd. Pulling in changes from
oslo-incubator requires dependencies from within oslo-incubator and
explains pulling in other modules outside of log.py. These other modules
are going to be used with notification work (specifically notifier/ and
rpc/ modules).

blueprint unified-logging-in-keystone

Change-Id: I9f7072dcbbb4609fa573501a9f2b55e8849b790a
"}]
commit_message:
Unified logging strategy from oslo-incubator

This commit introduces a unified logging strategy from oslo-incubator in
an attempt to standardize logging in Keystone similar to other OpenStack
projects (Nova, Quantum, etc.). This commit keeps
keystone/common/config.py as a wrapper to
keystone/openstack/common/log.py
but instead of carrying out logging setup in config.py it calls into
setup() within log.py.

This change contains changes from oslo-incubator to existing files in
Keystone, in which case those files were sync'd. Pulling in changes from
oslo-incubator requires dependencies from within oslo-incubator and
explains pulling in other modules outside of log.py. These other modules
are going to be used with notification work (specifically notifier/ and
rpc/ modules).

blueprint unified-logging-in-keystone

Change-Id: I9f7072dcbbb4609fa573501a9f2b55e8849b790a

subject: Add virt-driver prefix check
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1, 'name': 'James E. Blair', 'email': 'jim@acmegating.com', 'username': 'corvus'}, {'_account_id': 2, 'name': 'Monty Taylor', 'email': 'mordred@inaugust.com', 'username': 'mordred'}, {'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-05-24 22:44:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Pending https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30482/ merging into hacking'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-24 23:32:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30504/1/check/gate-nova-pep8/26929 : SUCCESS in 2m 59s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/30504/1/check/gate-nova-docs/21149/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 29s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30504/1/check/gate-nova-python26/22551 : SUCCESS in 12m 32s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30504/1/check/gate-nova-python27/22640 : SUCCESS in 8m 36s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30504/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/18455 : SUCCESS in 48m 57s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30504/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/18165 : FAILURE in 44m 48s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/30504/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/25238 : SUCCESS in 20m 48s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30504/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/5909 : FAILURE in 16m 44s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/30504/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/12314 : SUCCESS in 9m 28s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-28 11:19:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

-2, I think this requires further discussion.  The original patch went in fairly quickly without any discussion.  Pending outcome of further discussion I am happy to remove my -2 if enough people disagree with me.

I don't think we should have this requirement in nova's HACKING at all. The original commit (I376d2cdb5dc344717fb7749a80e33ee88603e68c) message provides to reasons for this rule:

1) "Prefixing the commit message's first line with the driver makes it easier for reviewers, at a glance, to find reviews that relate to their area of expertise"

2) "improving the overall readability of the git history"


I disagree with both motivations:

1) Adding this requirement makes the usable title space much smaller, we already limit the length. Also this rule doesn't fit the motivation, it only helps for virt drivers. furthermore there is a strong argument to be made about wanting to pay extra attention to patches that touch specific files or directories.  This should be done in gerrit or in email filters locally, not in a git commit rule.  I would love to have gerrit do this, but short of that gerrits email show what files are touched -- enough information to filter on.

2) if you want to see what patches changed a driver, just do a 'git history driver/name.py''}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-05-28 18:13:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> 2, I think this requires further discussion. The original patch went in fairly quickly without any discussion. Pending outcome of further discussion I am happy to remove my -2 if enough people disagree with me.

Another more generous way to look at it is that no discussion was needed
because it was such an obvious win :-).

I don't think this is a contraversial idea, especially for large projects that
have lots of sub-systems with a relatively well-defined sets of sub-system
maintainers. The Linux kernel has used this approach for a while now, since
before 2005 [1][2], for these exact reasons. 

I'm sure Linus knows that he can use `git log --stat` to find out which files have been touched, but prefixing the subsystem makes it much easier for maintainers to zero in on patches relevant to them.


> Pending outcome of further discussion I am happy to remove my -2 if enough people disagree with me.

The HACKING.RST change received two core-dev approvals and a `recheck` from the PTL at the time (which seems like tacit approval to me!).

Given that this went in over 9 months ago, has 85 commits that follow this style, and that this is the *first* objection, it feels like defaulting to -2 is a bit harsh.


> 1) Adding this requirement makes the usable title space much smaller, we already limit the length.

True, it means less usable space, that's a trade-off. All I can point to is
that in practice:

* So far no one has objected despite this recommendation having been in place and *used* for 9 months

* This doesn't seem to bother kernel devs who also have strict commit message style guidelines including title-length limit


> Also this rule doesn't fit the motivation, it only helps for virt drivers.

Not all parts of the Nova code base have sub- systems with relatively well-defined sets of maintainers. 

Virt-drivers are probably the most obvious case, so the idea was to start with there, and to over time organically grow which subsystems should use the prefix.

Another place where it might make sense is the RPC drivers, `kombu` vs
`zeromq`. Perhaps `cells` would be another use-case.


> furthermore there is a strong argument to be made about wanting to pay extra attention to patches that touch specific files or directories. This should be done in gerrit or in email filters locally, not in a git commit rule. I would love to have gerrit do this, but short of that gerrits email show what files are touched -- enough information to filter on.

Having Gerrit notify on certain 'watched' files and directories is a cool
idea, but it's not the same.

The whole point of the prefix is to annotate in a universal, easily
discoverable location, which subsystem is affected. Putting it anywhere
outside the title of the commit msg would lose this benefit.



----
[1] https://lkml.org/lkml/2005/4/7/183
[2] http://www.scourge.fr/mathdesc/documents/kernel/perfectpatch.txt"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-28 21:23:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Rick, you make a strong argument about why linux kernel uses this format.  My concern here is not that this doesn't work, but that we have a different development process then linux kernel on several levels (we have gerrit, we don't have to review patches via email only, etc). And there may be a more general solution to this problem, that we can fairly easily roll out to all projects in a more automated fashion.

Note: I am not against doing this just hesitant to enforcing it and saying this is the right solution.

asking for feedback from the infra team"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-28 21:37:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

because you can put a watch on just a file portion of a tree in gerrit, I'm not really convinced this is a good idea to enforce in policy anyway.

If the ship has sailed, so be it, but it seems odd to me."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-05-28 21:53:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Just to clarify: I'm not arguing against having Gerrit grow a subsystem-annotation feature that eventually replaces the prefix if it proves just as usable.

The only thing I'm arguing for is that we keep using the prefix in places where we've been using it successfully for 9 months, and that we add an automated check to enforce the rule consistently, like we do for many other conventions.

That said, I don't think Watch-Files and client-filtering scripts (Greasemonkey or whatever) are sufficient here; I think this is useful and well-defined enough that it should be baked into the canonical workflow, be it a Gerritt dropdown or Git commit-msg prefix."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-28 22:14:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

looks like we all (at least mostly) agree this should be a CI feature: https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ci/+bug/1185184

while this may be a good interim solution, still -1 since I think we need to evaluate gerrit watching subtrees better before we gate on this."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-05 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-05 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-24 22:43:12.000000000', 'message': "Add virt-driver prefix check

We have a style requirement in Nova that if a change only affects a specific
virt-driver,  the commit title should be prefixed with the driver-name, a
colon, and a space.

This patch adds a check to detect trivial cases where the only files that
changed were under a directories related to a given virt-driver. This check
shouldn't generate any false positives but could miss out on changes that have
small changes in non virt-specific files. Over time we can refine the check to
eliminate more and more these false negatives.

Change-Id: Ic27d6f569160f15bc230595b343a79a1798944ee
"}]
commit_message:
Add virt-driver prefix check

We have a style requirement in Nova that if a change only affects a specific
virt-driver,  the commit title should be prefixed with the driver-name, a
colon, and a space.

This patch adds a check to detect trivial cases where the only files that
changed were under a directories related to a given virt-driver. This check
shouldn't generate any false positives but could miss out on changes that have
small changes in non virt-specific files. Over time we can refine the check to
eliminate more and more these false negatives.

Change-Id: Ic27d6f569160f15bc230595b343a79a1798944ee

commit_message:
Get the updated subnet info. from the DB directly

The solution prevents getting the outdated subnet
information from the cache after the subnet updated.

Also this patch moved the DB related operations into
the subtransactions.

Fixes: bug #1080550

Change-Id: I8840fea7e9e2797007826c989528c190f197da2b

I like the change, but I don't like the name "validate" because it's so vague. Maybe call it "expand_request_path"* or something instead? I mean, it does more than just validate arguments; it does some path parsing too, and expands that out to keyword args that weren't there originally.

* seriously just a suggestion, and not even necessarily any good'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-13 19:52:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Based on IRC discussions, marking as a work in progress to see if we can't address some of the concerns brought up about naming and argument passing."}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-21 03:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Chuck, just wanted to record your objections posted on IRC. Let me know if I do not represent them properly.

The method signature of the routine and that of what the caller expects is different, where the decorator fills in the missing parameters automagically.

Would having the decorator add attributes to the request object be acceptable?'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-26 01:05:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-26 01:51:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

- http://logs.openstack.org/28991/2/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/5984 : SUCCESS in 14m 12s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-29 01:59:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not a big fan of the added arguments here. I agree with Chuck; it's confusing to have arguments appear out of nowhere on a method call. I'd rather have two calls to split_path (one in the decorator, one in the method) than have magically-appearing arguments. If others really like it, though, they can certainly override me.

Note that you'd still save code since, in GET/POST/etc., you could call split_path without the try/except.

If you're going to go the route of adding them to the request, I'd add them to `req.path`, e.g. `req.path.device`. I think it reads better than `req.device`.

Also, I'll suggest "validate_request_path" as a name for the decorator. IMO, the extra verbosity is worth the clarity.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-29 03:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Good suggestions. I am favoring the request.path route, will re-post when I get a chance to formulate it all. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-05 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-05 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

commit_message:
Enable quantum-ovs-cleanup service where it exists

Red Hat-based distros have a service which calls the
quantum-ovs-cleanup binary when appropriate. It doesn't appear that
non-Red Hat-based distros have this service.

Change-Id: I8050127265450014815813ef3c56126252e6feac

commit_message:
Customizable allowed_sync_hosts in container-server.conf

Insert default value into .conf file (127.0.0.1) or use
custom value if specified.

Change-Id: I9caec9657a2a3ad789b7dab646e505f609c25655

[{'created': '2013-06-04 03:50:32.000000000', 'message': 'Add the first package

https://pypi.python.org/pypi/first
https://github.com/hynek/first

This is a one function package that helps neaten up a bunch of code
and is really easy to read (idiomatic/idiot proof).

If we are ok with copying MIT code into oslo I could add it there since
it is so small. I am easy with both approaches.

Change-Id: I543878e7d4dac94947976b606368d25bc179897c
'}]
commit_message:
Add the first package

https://pypi.python.org/pypi/first
https://github.com/hynek/first

This is a one function package that helps neaten up a bunch of code
and is really easy to read (idiomatic/idiot proof).

If we are ok with copying MIT code into oslo I could add it there since
it is so small. I am easy with both approaches.

Change-Id: I543878e7d4dac94947976b606368d25bc179897c

commit_message:
Replace FLAGS with cfg.CONF in db

Replace all the FLAGS with cfg.CONF in cinder/db
Large commit "https://review.openstack.org/31172" was split into several parts
Use the common pattern: CONF = cfg.CONF

Change-Id: Ibac0a4b233ba82e13e3a9bfb6bd3fd418cdab29f
Fixes: bug #1182037

commit_message:
Add tests for encodings

The patch adds tests for headers encodings, incoming data decoding,
outgoing meta encoding and filters encoding.

Fixes bug: #1187013

commit_message:
Don't log warn if v3 API is disabled.

This makes sense because the V3 API is disabled by default.

Fixes LP Bug #1187217.

Change-Id: I1f182fa480bfef19dbe6d4b575200100fe2ee515

commit_message:
Add Fn::Select template function

It also knows how to lookup keys in dict's too.
The strings can be a serialized json blob too.

blueprint fn-select
blueprint fn-mapselect
Change-Id: Ie40afa47c1f0a699abb852bc22388f3f675172e6

messages:

I want to do this in a slightly different way.'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-04 05:58:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-04 05:59:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/31595/2/check/gate-heat-requirements/52 : Incompatible requirement found; see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Requirements in 8s
- http://logs.openstack.org/31595/2/check/gate-heat-pep8/3325 : FAILURE in 11s
- http://logs.openstack.org/31595/2/check/gate-heat-python26/3280 : FAILURE in 1m 11s
- http://logs.openstack.org/31595/2/check/gate-heat-python27/3279 : FAILURE in 14s
"}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-06-04 15:13:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

while i think this would be a fine short-term answer to validating this particular issue, the proposed parameter validation changes are a more generic mechanism to add new validation without having to go into each resource or the parameter code itself each time there are new validation requirements.'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-06-04 15:31:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Randall: do you have a link to the more generic parameter validation proposal you mentioned?

My first reaction would be that validating such very specific parameters like an image ID (make sure that the image exists) is best done in the resources that really understand the details. Imagine another resource implementation that gets its images from some custom repo (for whatever reason).

... but maybe having more details about your proposal will teach me better :-)'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-06-04 16:31:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Thomas: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/param-constraints (welcome back, btw; hope your vacation was good!)'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-06-04 16:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Randall: Thanks, that was helpful.

So in general, that more powerful parameter validation, maybe even pluggable makes sense. The question is how smart it should really be. E.g. should it really do something like invoing APIs of OS services?

Resource implementations are really specific to their environment, so they have to talk to OS services, and then maybe also should do more complex validation that involves calling other services. Another aspect to consider is this provider resource thing. If we have different providers for a type of resource, each provide might have to validate differently, so it would be a validate() on the resource.

Anyway, there are pros & cons for both paths. The important point is finding the right dividing line ...'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-06-04 17:40:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Good points, but the param/input validation BP isn't meant to replace any resource specific validation. Things like being able to use a glance repo or nova service to do some validation up front isn't unreasonable in an Openstack focused template engine, IMO. Probably best to have this discussion on the BP and/or ML though."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-04 23:19:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-05 03:44:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Abandoned

I'll can this for now..."}]

commit_message:
Check for the image existing in validate()

This may go someway to resolve blueprint glance-parameter-constraint
Add first() to requirements to neaten things up.

This depends on: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/31602

Change-Id: I85befe4672668fb9a3e5f1b424e12b3473e3a77b

commit_message:
Make object actions pass positional arguments

This changes the Object API to also pass positional arguments
to remotable methods. Previously, we required only keyword arguments
to these methods in order to mirror our current RPC behavior.
This is not really necessary and could be confusing.

Since there are no actual users of these APIs in the tree right
now, we can make this change without needing to bump any versions.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: Ifb12843d16500d383d4e9c607121d5584400f247

commit_message:
Move sql_connection option into sqlalchemy package.

Since we're in the process of adding new backends that don't use
sql_connection, it makes sense to move that option into the sqlalchemy
package. That's what this patch does.

As for glance-manage, it now calls the add_cli_options directly from
sqlalchemy's api module.

This is part of the blueprint registry-db-driver

Change-Id: I890a5f707fe18f397cbeaadbac1d693ead2fdc14

[{'created': '2013-06-05 02:24:58.000000000', 'message': 'Set pipefail on init-quantum to detect faiures.

Even with the sleeps in the upstart jobs, sometimes we still lose the
race with quantum-server. This makes quantum net-create fail. We should
stop init-quantum right then, but because it is being piped to other
commands, the failure is not detected.

Pipefail will make sure that we detect any of these failures and stop
the process.

Change-Id: I9f5f3863903aa6abd816841dd71133d24ffe6358
'}, {'created': '2013-06-05 02:24:58.000000000', 'message': 'Set pipefail on init-quantum to detect failures.

Even with the sleeps in the upstart jobs, sometimes we still lose the
race with quantum-server. This makes quantum net-create fail. We should
stop init-quantum right then, but because it is being piped to other
commands, the failure is not detected.

Pipefail will make sure that we detect any of these failures and stop
the process.

Change-Id: I9f5f3863903aa6abd816841dd71133d24ffe6358
'}]
commit_message:
Set pipefail on init-quantum to detect failures.

Even with the sleeps in the upstart jobs, sometimes we still lose the
race with quantum-server. This makes quantum net-create fail. We should
stop init-quantum right then, but because it is being piped to other
commands, the failure is not detected.

Pipefail will make sure that we detect any of these failures and stop
the process.

Change-Id: I9f5f3863903aa6abd816841dd71133d24ffe6358

commit_message:
cfn-get-metadata: log metadata to standard output

Add display() method to the Metadata class that prints the metadata to
standard output if the metdata has been successfully retrieved (either
from local cache or from the remote server).

Change-Id: Idf6c1aecf2a5204d7cf7fbf3c8d826f750a72785
Fixes: bug #1183298

[{'created': '2013-06-04 05:52:03.000000000', 'message': 'For Fn::Join, replace None items with an empty string.

Currently, attempts to join lists with None items results in an error.

This change is required for the next attempt to fix bug: #1184794

Change-Id: Ib599eeb21b7325ff797768100f1556a424a8bde9
'}]
commit_message:
For Fn::Join, replace None items with an empty string.

Currently, attempts to join lists with None items results in an error.

This change is required for the next attempt to fix bug: #1184794

Change-Id: Ib599eeb21b7325ff797768100f1556a424a8bde9

commit_message:
_s3_create handles image being deleted

Change so _s3_create handles the image it is creating
being deleted while it is creating it without logging a stacktrace
and instead just logging a simple message explaining what happened.

Fixes bug 1084703

Change-Id: I9d984dd1cf4f393010493cacd048d20ad5225db8

commit_message:
Fixes the 3PAR drivers CPG validation

The 3PAR drivers were not checking if the Common Provisioning
Group(CPG) exists in the virtual domain at volume create time when
the default was being overwritten by volume type extra_specs value.
It was also reporting the default CPG in the metadata returning
after creating the volume. Now it reporting the correct CPG and
setting the correct snapshot cpg if different from the default
or not set.

Fixes bug 1186427

Change-Id: Idef7a4f29854c82980789786f2414e5046c8d8fb

[{'created': '2013-06-03 16:55:23.000000000', 'message': "Make instance object tolerate isotime strings

Any time we get a db object over RPC, the datetime has been
serialized to an isotime string. We have other legacy code that
needs to tolerate this, and those hacks would need to be
replicated in the objects transition. Instead, make the instance
object type function tolerate isotime-formatted strings so that
we can more easily convert RPC-transited database objects
until we're fully converted, at which time we could remove the
tolerance. Luckily, the objects still end up with a datetime
internally, which means the rest of the code can stop needing to
handle strings and datetimes gracefully.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

commit_message:
Make instance object tolerate isotime strings

Any time we get a db object over RPC, the datetime has been
serialized to an isotime string. We have other legacy code that
needs to tolerate this, and those hacks would need to be
replicated in the objects transition. Instead, make the instance
object type function tolerate isotime-formatted strings so that
we can more easily convert RPC-transited database objects
until we're fully converted, at which time we could remove the
tolerance. Luckily, the objects still end up with a datetime
internally, which means the rest of the code can stop needing to
handle strings and datetimes gracefully.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I132559d3541d19353de6acc36a2740185e564105

commit_message:
Add fake_instance.py

There are lots of places in the tests where we create a piece of
an instance-like dict and return that from a stubbed database
function. This "works" right now, but won't in the future of stricter
objects. This adds a fake_instance.py (to mirror the other ones
already there) which builds an instance database primitive that
includes sane values for every field it should have. This will make
testing much easier going forward with instance objects.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I13d97cc101c1964aa91ce48093507bbc88803cbb

commit_message:
Enhance multipath parsing

The output of the multipath command is not always parseable from
the current implementation. This causes attach to fail.

Fixes Bug: #1184861

Change-Id: I1afa96a695b1008672226e7e76eb8e0feca52578

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 10:13:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

-1 mostly just because of the placement of the spawn.  And ahhhh the joys of unit tests not being unit tests causing you pain :)    I wonder if you move the spawn to the conductor LocalAPI if it makes it easier to stub.  You could stub LocalAPI.run_instance for example.

And one other minor comment:  I've always disliked the scheduler and compute methods being 'run_instance'.   What do you feel about calling the conductor method simply 'build_instance' ?"}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-05-15 14:28:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

If the scheduler is going to become a lookup service, neither "run_instance" nor "build_instance" seems appropriate.  Something like "pick_hosts" might be better.  

I agree with Chris on the placement of the spawn.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-15 19:26:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

Thanks for the comments.

Chris, build_instance works for me.  I still struggle with the fact that it could be one or many, but changing request_spec means a lot of changes in other places so I'm going to defer that struggle until later.

Brian, I definitely agree with you.  My next patch is going to introduce a new method on the scheduler which will be named appropriately, or at least better."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:54:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:55:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 22:14:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I haven't looked at the latest patch sets yet, but in reply to some of the inline comments:

@belliott: I think 'build_instance' makes sense for the cast to conductor.  It then does whatever it needs to do to build it.  The new call to the scheduler (which will come in a later patch set) I do think would be better named as something like 'pick_hosts' or 'select_hosts' or something.

@alaski: Yeah on the multiple instances thing.  Maybe the conductor method should be plural.  'build_instances' ? :)

And regarding the circular import... This is a lot more code to move around, but I think this solves the problem and makes a little more sense:

Move the current 'create' call from compute_api to conductor_api.  Modify the nova/api code to call conductor_api.create().

I think this makes more sense since the build process will now be the responsibility of conductor, not compute.  And it removes the need to import conductor_api from compute_api."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 22:41:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/29091/4/check/gate-nova-pep8/25962 : SUCCESS in 2m 56s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29091/4/check/gate-nova-docs/20180/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 21s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29091/4/check/gate-nova-python26/21586 : FAILURE in 13m 41s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29091/4/check/gate-nova-python27/21676 : FAILURE in 8m 24s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29091/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/16187 : SUCCESS in 42m 59s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29091/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/15903 : FAILURE in 45m 15s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/29091/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/22687 : SUCCESS in 21m 30s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29091/4/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/3799 : FAILURE in 11m 27s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/29091/4/check/gate-nova-pylint/11578 : SUCCESS in 7m 48s (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-15 22:45:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@comstud: Moving create to conductor is definitely an option.  John went that way with his live-migrate patch, although it was api -> conductor -> compute api which is a little bit different and works because there's no return information necessary.  But going down the nova/api -> conductor route moves a lot of policy and validation logic into conductor which I don't think is the right move.  And it requires a call in this case which removes some of the benefit we gain from pushing it to conductor."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-15 22:48:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 23:39:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build succeeded.

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 23:58:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@alaski:  I suggested (or meant to suggest) moving create() to conductor/api.py NOT the manager. :)  And then change nova/api to call conductor_api.create().  The bulk of the work would still occur in nova-api, it's just that the code is in conductor/api not compute/api.  It would avoid the circular ref problem.  Policy becomes a little weird.  You'd maybe still use the 'compute' scope even though the code is in conductor/api.py to avoid having to deal with changing the scope to 'conductor', heh."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-16 00:34:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@comstud: I glossed over the conductor api part, that solves the cast/call issue.  My main concern is that there's really a lot of non orchestration work that happens in compute before it goes the the scheduler/conductor.  It can be made to work in the conductor, it just doesn't seem to be the right place for it.  But I'll play around with some things tomorrow and see how it looks."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-16 01:27:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@alaski: Ya, I know what you're talking about.  I guess I'm curious to see what it looks like, too.  I tend to picture nova-conductor somewhat becoming a replacement for nova-compute in the long run... such that the only thing left in nova-compute are things that absolutely must run on each host.. like image handling code, etc.  What this means to me is that nova-api never talks directly to nova-compute anymore and instead talks to nova-conductor..  And I tend to think that means it makes sense to move compute/api code into conductor/api.  But I have no idea what others think ;)"}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-16 02:07:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@comstud:  Now I see.  I was picturing it the other way.  nova_api -> compute_api -> conductor api/manager -> compute_manager.  I'm not sure how much value that really provides over shifting compute_api into conductor_api though.  I started envisioning compute_api as a policy enforcement and precondition check layer for quick failures, but maybe that doesn't need to be broken out.

I'll shift some things around and maybe tomorrow we can discuss in a more realtime format :)"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-16 02:46:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

sounds good :)'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-16 12:36:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I agree with the vision for nova-conductor taking over much of what the nova-compute service does, but not I'm not as convinced about moving code from compute.api into conductor.api.

Here's the way I see these APIs:

nova.compute.api - Client side (primarily nova-api) of compute operations.  To complete the requested operations, it may do some things locally, may talk to compute nodes, or may defer long running task processing to nova-conductor.

nova.conductor.api - The client side API for talking to conductor.  It's called by nova.compute.manager to handle remote database access.  It's also called by other client side APIs such as nova.compute.api to kick off a task for conductor to process.


From the nova-api code, I don't think it should have to know about conductor.  It's an implementation detail.  It just knows that it has a compute operation that needs to happen, so it calls the compute API."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-16 12:38:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

So basically I like the way this is set up right now.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-16 15:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Yeah, I think I buy that.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-16 17:56:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-16 18:01:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Anyway, my concern is that 1) there's a behavior change here that's not documented in the commit reason. 2) the behavior change impacts performance for those who use the multi-instance boot feature. 3) there's a potential use case for the scheduler knowing it is building > 1 instance.

It sucks, because I know this would simplify the code considerably. :)"}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:08:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

Ditto to Chris's concern about batch scheduling.  We have supported it in the past.  It certainly would be convenient top drop it, though I think there is a fair amount of community interest based on summit discussion.  

The ability to efficiently schedule a big block of instances does seems useful.

Also, how does this interact with cells?  Right now cells works by hacking over the scheduler rpc function to cast to the cells service.  This change bypasses cells, right?"}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:11:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'created': '2013-05-29 20:25:05.000000000', 'message': 'Call scheduler for run_instance from conductor

This prepares for having the conductor query the scheduler for a list of
hosts to build an instance on.  In order to accomplish this the API
sends a build_instances message to conductor, or spawns a greenthread in
local mode, rather than sending a message to the scheduler.  This is
being done so that conductor can handle the orchestration of long
running tasks like spawning instances.  By making this move, the API is
free to return to the caller while conductor queries the scheduler for a
host to provision to.

In the case of cells the build_instances message first goes to the
cells scheduler in order to pick a cell to send it to, and then it is
sent to the conductor in that cell.

Part of bp query-scheduler
Change-Id: I4539888e78ebdbb8cef6647273b959a012280110

being done so that conductor can handle the orchestration of long
running tasks like spawning instances.  By making this move, the API is
free to return to the caller while conductor queries the scheduler for a
host to provision to.

In the case of cells the build_instances message first goes to the
cells scheduler in order to pick a cell to send it to, and then it is
sent to the conductor in that cell.

cells scheduler in order to pick a cell to send it to, and then it is
sent to the conductor in that cell.

Part of bp query-scheduler
Change-Id: I4539888e78ebdbb8cef6647273b959a012280110
'}]
commit_message:
Call scheduler for run_instance from conductor

This prepares for having the conductor query the scheduler for a list of
hosts to build an instance on.  In order to accomplish this the API
sends a build_instances message to conductor, or spawns a greenthread in
local mode, rather than sending a message to the scheduler.  This is
being done so that conductor can handle the orchestration of long
running tasks like spawning instances.  By making this move, the API is
free to return to the caller while conductor queries the scheduler for a
host to provision to.

In the case of cells the build_instances message first goes to the
cells scheduler in order to pick a cell to send it to, and then it is
sent to the conductor in that cell.

Part of bp query-scheduler
Change-Id: I4539888e78ebdbb8cef6647273b959a012280110

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-24 01:46:07.000000000', 'message': "IPMI driver sets bootdev option persistently.

This patch changes baremetal ipmi driver's behavior with regards to
setting the chassis boot device.

Previous behavior: set bootdev = pxe for next boot only.
New behavior: set bootdev = pxe persistently.

Fixes bug 1178092

Change-Id: I735965422a950fbd249414b5eecd0a1b21dbabea
"}]
commit_message:
IPMI driver sets bootdev option persistently.

This patch changes baremetal ipmi driver's behavior with regards to
setting the chassis boot device.

Previous behavior: set bootdev = pxe for next boot only.
New behavior: set bootdev = pxe persistently.

Fixes bug 1178092

Change-Id: I735965422a950fbd249414b5eecd0a1b21dbabea

commit_message:
Add edit buttons for vip, member and monitor

Add options for updating vip, member and health monitor
attributes on load balancers table pages.
The following attributes can be updated:

Vip:
* name
* description
* pool_id
* session_persistence
* connection_limit
* admin_state_up

Member:
* pool_id
* weight
* admin_state_up

Health monitor:
* delay
* timeout
* max_retries
* admin_state_up

fixes bug 1171854

Change-Id: I117a67476e21c01fec5cb1d9440daeb343d3b341

commit_message:
Add RAM/disk requirements to image details

If an image has minimum disk or memory requirements, they should
be displayed in Image Detail page.

Change-Id: Ic7e75a8272c118a2e258f938c71da19746b4f0b8
Fixes: bug #1183563

commit_message:
Adds methods for [] & len into LazyURLPattern

The Django 404 page currently depends on being able to call len()
and index LazyURLPattern.  However, the special methods for doing
this (__len__() and __getitem__()) are not forwarded to the object
wrapped by SimpleLazyObject by default.  Thus, methods to foward
these special methods to the wrapped object have been implemented
in LazyURLPattern.

Fixes: bug 1183578
Change-Id: I133e97ed66180fe78cfe1b7fd9c86bac4171a994

It isn't my plan for the short term. What's your take on it? Should we add puppet-lint as a non voting reviewer?"}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-05-08 22:42:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think I want to see it as a gate (added to the unit tests,not just a +1). I could be convinced that a +1 is just as good.

The reason is that as we get people that are new, we should have something automatically doing basic syntax/style review (we'll have to ensure that the messages are clear enough to direct newbies). Even though puppet-lint can be quite nit-picky, it's way better than nothing."}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-05-08 22:43:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

subject: Tolerate missing handle in WaitCondition FnGetAtt
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-27 22:10:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30647/1/check/gate-heat-pep8/3220 : SUCCESS in 1m 23s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30647/1/check/gate-heat-python26/3175 : SUCCESS in 1m 56s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30647/1/check/gate-heat-python27/3174 : SUCCESS in 1m 29s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30647/1/check/dev-heat-coverage/1559 : FAILURE in 11s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-05-27 23:10:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-05-28 00:46:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-28 00:48:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30647/2/check/gate-heat-pep8/3223 : SUCCESS in 1m 34s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30647/2/check/gate-heat-python26/3178 : SUCCESS in 2m 02s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30647/2/check/gate-heat-python27/3177 : SUCCESS in 1m 41s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30647/2/check/dev-heat-coverage/1560 : FAILURE in 12s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-05-28 11:05:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-28 14:56:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

This seems like a bit of a hack, and it doesn't address the underlying issue, which is that "Fn::GetAtt" should add a dependency in the same way that "Ref" does.'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-05-28 21:21:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Suppresing errors is indeed bad, and I don't like the "shotgun" approach. Also this changes behavior without a test case, so -1 for that as well.

Finally, I don't believe the bug is a bug at all.

I think the template that exposes this problem should really be using DependsOn to get the ordering right. The whole point of having separate WaitConditionHandle and WaitCondition is that you can create the WaitConditionHandle first, feed it to the instance that needs it, and then the WaitCondition should depend on the instance. The instance has access to any data that would be produced by cfn-signal since it triggers cfn-signal itself, and so there's no need to support that instance using Fn::GetAtt itself.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-05-28 23:41:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I had assumed that this wasn't a dependencies issue, but that the template gets evaluated before create even starts. I've seen FnGetAtt get called before handle_create.

If that is what is happening here a better fix might be to never call a resources FnGetAtt unless it is in CREATE_COMPLETE."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-04 21:10:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Trying an alternative approach https://review.openstack.org/#/c/31608/'}]

commit_message:
Bring back support for xen,lxc and qemu

The packages to install are now attributes.

Change-Id: I84ce8ba5960bfaf93b9b239631499e9f6ba56aae

commit_message:
Sort #memcached_servers results

Chef 11 doesn't seem to return sorted results.  The results
of this method need sorted, to prevent template changes, and
unnecessary service restarts.

Change-Id: I7b8864515cd2f4140f72d5ac430cd330a530cab2

commit_message:
Add simple plugin calls and cluster status updates

* provisioning plugin is now called while cluster creation
* cluster status is now updated while cluster creation

Change-Id: I7103589ab3ebe1079079d1773384633a89b1aba0

commit_message:
Fix postgresql failures related to Data type

Postgresql is kind of sensitive about different kind of data in a query, so it
was failing in cases like lookin for an ip using a filter which wasn't a valid
ip or ids values greater than the id type on the table.

This patch fix this behavior to fixed ips and floating ips.

Fixes bug 1182754

Change-Id: I83d532c28c9aec690e8e1ffad8b58e71d619d728

    def temporary_chown(path, owner_uid=None)

Implements: blueprint image-tools

commit_message:
WIP - Add common code to fetch images.

This code is present in nova, cinder and also needed by ironic package.

List of new files/methods and origin:

openstack/common/image/image_utils.py => nova.virt.images <=> cincer.iamges.image_utils

openstack/common/exception.py => nova.exception <=> cinder.exception
    class ImageUnacceptable(Invalid)

openstack/common/fileutils.py => nova.utils <=> cinder.utils
    def temporary_chown(path, owner_uid=None)
    def file_open(*args, **kwargs)

openstack/common/strutils.py => nova.utils <=> cinder.utils
    def to_bytes(text, default=0)

openstack/common/processutils.py => NEW
    def execute_wrapper(*cmd, **kwargs):

    This new method allows project's execute() to insert rootwrap configuration into
    oslo's execute() method kwargs.

Change-Id: Ia750099372b048c328ea230a5faaf5184f7c49e1
Implements: blueprint image-tools

And also, the build still has errors, but produces a result. 

If you don't want to build yourself, go to https://region-b.geo-1.objects.hpcloudsvc.com/v1/87135022548315/object-api/os-objectstorage-devguide-1.0.pdf"}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2013-05-17 18:17:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I didn't put it in the docs for some not great reason but it basically works the way you'd think it would.  A COPY will basically make a new object based on a GET of the source file.  A GET of a slo object returns the concatenation of all the segments so a COPY based on that GET is the combined object (with the x-static-large-object header removed).  If  the GET has a "&multipart-manifest=get" query parameter then you get the actual manifest.  A COPY based on that GET will just make a new slo manifest object and keep the x-static-large-object header. The new object will be an SLO just like the first one.'}, {'account_id': 860, 'date': '2013-05-23 08:30:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

In case this is not clear to other reviewers, David is commenting on SLO itself - not the doc changes. I believe patch set 3 is in line with David's comments."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:53:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:53:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Add static large object to object-api

Add static large object description to Swift Developer Guide.
Renamed existing large object to dynamic large objects.
Updated affected operations (COPY, DELETE)

Bug 1176037

commit_message:
Replace FLAGS with cfg.CONF in scheduler

Replace all the FLAGS with cfg.CONF in cinder/scheduler
Large commit "https://review.openstack.org/31172" was split into several parts
Use the common pattern: CONF = cfg.CONF

Change-Id: If293d36a9e1552f7af497edf947e82458488bf9c
Fixes: bug #1182037

instance is being built, however it is not a column in the DB nor is it

"}, {'created': '2013-05-31 20:24:04.000000000', 'message': "Remove unused launch_time from instance

commit_message:
Remove unused launch_time from instance

'launch_time' is passed around as part of instance properties when an
instance is being built, however it is not a column in the DB nor is it
even used anywhere.

It was also unnecessarily copied around in various tests.

This patch removes all references to it.

Change-Id: I2300cd6b8539d15bbcd35ab4c00ab99d4be13eb5

Imagine you have thousands of containers, / would be used to order them in a directory like hierarchy.  I imagine that this is also useful if you are doing a similar thing for objects. revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 15:37:50.000000000', 'message': "Change to use dash instead of slash

It is not entirely clear how someone would end up with '/' in the container
names, unless they go through the trouble of escaping them in the URL. It
would seem that the more common case would be some other character. To
validate this we change to using '-'.

It should also be noted that the documentation for container listing, found
here:
http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-object-storage/1.0/content/s_listcontainers.html,
does not document the use of the prefix or delimiter parameters.

Change-Id: Ie467a4181c6f64b24c82c72b70a37183d443dee1
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2013-06-03 23:28:58.000000000', 'message': "Change to use dash instead of slash

commit_message:
Change to use dash instead of slash

There is no known way to embed slashes into container names, even when
using URL escape sequences. Since it would seem that the more common
case would be some other character, we validate using a dash ('-')
character as the delimiter.

It should also be noted that the documentation for container listing,
found here:
http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-object-storage/1.0/content/s_listcontainers.html,
does not describe the use of the prefix or delimiter parameters.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ie467a4181c6f64b24c82c72b70a37183d443dee1
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add availability zone choice to launch instance

Fixes: bug #1186075
Implements: blueprint select-zone-when-creating-instance

* Updated project.instances.tests to include availability zone
  information where required

Change-Id: I14272a94b90587575776142da82413db88f5a99c

- http://logs.openstack.org/21262/3/check/gate-nova-pylint/7732 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1007, 'date': '2013-02-09 06:52:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

nova-conductor recently landed which removes direct db access from the compute nodes. Should update db calls to call ConductorAPI and add the appropriate changes to nova.conductor."}, {'account_id': 1007, 'date': '2013-02-09 06:55:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Forgot to link nova-conductor spec. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/no-db-compute'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2013-02-11 14:35:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

In order for snapshots, clone and backup to work, I think key <-> volume associations fundamentally need to be known to cinder, not just nova."}, {'account_id': 2064, 'date': '2013-02-11 17:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

If a "Unique Identifier" was attached to the meta-data of the volume and persisted in snapshots or backups, it would effectively be a pointer to the key required to access the data.

For more information about it, see Chapter 3.1 about KMIP "Unique Identifier" in http://docs.oasis-open.org/kmip/spec/v1.0/cs01/kmip-spec-1.0-cs-01.pdf 

The client sends a request to the key management system (KMIP server) for a “Get” operation, passing the unique identifier for the cryptographic object, for instance a symmetric encryption key that it needs to use to encrypt a particular information. The key management system returns attributes for that object, including not only the value for that key, but also other attributes, such as the kind of key (symmetric) and the unique identifier, that allow the client to be sure it is receiving the correct key. Headers for both the request and response provide information such as the protocol version and message identifiers that the participating systems can use to track and correlate the messages.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-02-12 23:14:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Do not merge

(As also noted on the blueprint) I think it's too late for this to be coming in for Grizzly.  I'd like to see a Havana design summit session on this and then have the code proposed for Havana."}, {'account_id': 6870, 'date': '2013-02-14 23:01:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Regarding the improvements introduced by the patch itself:

  - the "encryption support for volume" functionality should be a configurable option, not only for the client, but for the service provider as well. The introduction of volume encryption may have a significant impact on the performances of the system: operators should have the possibility to easily activate this option, without changing the code of the service. At the moment, the patch does not allow this.

  - currently, the granularity of the key identifier is the volume. As said previously, it could be problematic for volume snapshots and copies. Using the "owner id" field seems a better choice.

Regarding the approach proposed for key management: the externalization of the key manager as a transverse Openstack service (i.e. potentially addressed by others services than NOVA) would allow for strong separation of all "key consumers" and "key providers" within OpenStack. There is a need for a new service API that could be inspired by a simplified version of the KMIP protocol, and could itself implements, as a configurable plugin, a KMIP client or a database (like the one in the current patch).'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-22 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-22 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-05 23:30:25.000000000', 'message': 'Added encryption support for volumes

Added support to encrypt volumes. Modified the libvirt driver to encrypt
volumes during the attach call. Created a new VolumeEncryptor class that is
responsible for encrypting volumes. The default implementation does not do
enryption, and a DmCryptVolumeEncryptor is provided to encrypt volumes using
dmcrypt.

Added a new KeyManager interface. The KeyManager is used by the VolumeEncryptor
to retrieve the key necessary for encryption.

The following changes were made to Horizon to support this feature:

The modifications are to the volumes/cinder area of the dashboard. In the
cinder client's API, we exposed the metadata parameter in the "create" method,
and then added a choice field to the create form to (optionally) select an
encryption mode.  The user's selection is then passed in to cinder as volume
metadata.  We also modified the detailed volume view to display all metadata
associated with a volume.  Finally, we added a test case to exercise the
encryption choice field.

Change-Id: I6faac9661c2fd30dfa4bb67cd7802dd5426a199c
Implements: blueprint encrypt-cinder-volumes

commit_message:
Added encryption support for volumes

Added support to encrypt volumes. Modified the libvirt driver to
encrypt volumes during the attach call. Created a new VolumeEncryptor
class that is responsible for encrypting volumes. The default
implementation does not do enryption, and a DmCryptVolumeEncryptor is
provided to encrypt volumes using dmcrypt.

Added a new KeyManager interface. The KeyManager is used by the
VolumeEncryptor to retrieve the key necessary for encryption.

The following changes were made to Horizon to support this feature:

The modifications are to the volumes/cinder area of the dashboard. In
the cinder client's API, we exposed the metadata parameter in the
"create" method, and then added a choice field to the create form to
(optionally) select an encryption mode.  The user's selection is then
passed in to cinder as volume metadata.  We also modified the detailed
volume view to display all metadata associated with a volume.
Finally, we added a test case to exercise the encryption choice field.

Change-Id: I6faac9661c2fd30dfa4bb67cd7802dd5426a199c
Implements: blueprint encrypt-cinder-volumes

I am concerned about this change.  Many of the systems I have seen running OpenStack have /var/lib/cinder created as part of the installation but they then run using a user like 'cinder' that has no home directory.  Granted, this can be worked around by going back to setting signing_dir to /var/lib/cinder but it seems this change needs to be communicated.

Is there an appropriate place to document this?"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-05-29 01:29:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Jay:

When I run cinder (via packages) I'm running it via a user account which has $HOME set to /var/lib/cinder. So I think your concern is covered here. For example see the /etc/passwd snippet below:

cinder:x:165:165:OpenStack Cinder Daemons:/var/lib/cinder:/sbin/nologin

As far as backwards compat goes I believe this change should be quite safe... the keystone auth_token middleware will simply create a new signing dir within the existing old default tree (/var/lib/cinder)."}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2013-05-29 02:07:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Dan, You are correct.  It appears that the cinder user has /var/lib/cinder set for the home directory.  I was not aware of that.  So, that is most excellent!  That cover's my concerns.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-05-29 05:36:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2013-05-30 10:24:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Changing this to create a directory under home suddenly is a backwards compatibility problem - the old code behaved sensibly on a system with e.g. slow NFS home directories, where as this version won't."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-06-04 14:30:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Duncan: $HOME for the cinder user is typically /var/lib/cinder. So I think we are good here. See my comment above about /etc/passwd, etc.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-06-04 14:46:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Don't set signing_dir by default.

Allow the auth_token middleware to setup its own signing_dir
if required.

Fixes LP Bug #1185098.

Change-Id: Id8766efb34d37ca382b865167ec2465d0a1ce8dc

commit_message:
Reduce ZmqProxy dependence on Eventlet

Remove direct access to eventlet module
in the ZmqProxy class where viable methods are already
provided via monkey-patching or alternatives exist.

Specifically, this switches to using the time.sleep()
method and Queue(py2) / queue(py3) modules.

Additionally, ZmqProxy now spawns inside the existing
threadpool.

Advances blueprint optional-eventlet-rpc

Change-Id: If62649c1c084fba12fc4ab034fc1f04d0a2a5657

messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:01:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/31579/1/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-common-chef-lint/42 : SUCCESS in 3m 45s

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-06-04 02:09:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

I understand where you are going with this, and I do see why you want the openstack::packages attribute namespace, but I don't think this is going to work. I've highlighted in the inline comments my reservations about this approach.

Hoping to hear some feedback from others on this important review.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-06-04 08:02:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

How would this work from component recipes? Would we have to set the packages attributes inside the recipes? How will we keep the group of packages installed for each recipe separate if we use this scheme?

Maybe we should also discuss this on the mailing list since it's a big design change."}, {'account_id': 26, 'date': '2013-06-04 15:46:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It was discussed previously on the mailing list, but I'm going to withdraw the patch and think about it some more. The goal was to get rid of the many duplicate blocks of platform package blocks and surface the packages that were being installed better, but maybe just standardizing the attributes for packages is good enough."}, {'account_id': 26, 'date': '2013-06-04 15:46:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

The goal was to get rid of the many duplicate blocks of platform package blocks and surface the packages that were being installed better, but maybe just standardizing the attributes for packages is good enough.'}]

I have a question about create/accept API.  Is it intentional not to specify accepter in create transfer API call?  So anyone who has the correct auth of transfer is able to accept?'}, {'account_id': 951, 'date': '2013-05-27 09:34:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

We don't include the accepter project id in the "create-transfer" api request as it is sensitive information like a username or password. A user probably won't want to share this with the transferee.'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2013-05-29 12:33:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Implement DB migration for volume transfer BP

This patch implements the backend for volume transfers as specified in the
Volume transfer blueprint.

Change-Id: Id18e57942c3908e2539f3b0845263d0fbdd198f5
implement bp: volume-transfer

commit_message:
Add TaskManager tests and fix decorator.

Fix the require_exclusive_lock decorator so it works on both
functions and class methods.

Add unit tests for TaskManager and require_exclusive_lock().

Change-Id: I5b86b365cce1ceb2d4926634ebcb0b412740c37d

commit_message:
Mocked NodeManager can load and mock real drivers.

Allow get_mocked_node_manager to take parameters to specify
which drivers it should load and return, so that real drivers
can be mocked too.

Change-Id: I68a4b81d2156adada7caa5be91083aae11e6d758

'}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-05-29 22:32:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

per rsync man page:
--bwlimit=KBPS  //limit I/O bandwidth; KBytes per second

A value of zero implies no limit.
Most effective when used with large files, several megabytes and up and if a large block was sent over, greater than bwlimit, rsynch waits a bit .. to basically get the average transfer rate to be bwlimit.'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-05-31 08:35:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is a useful argument. But I think it will be better to add some describe at:

https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/etc/object-server.conf-sample#L86'}, {'account_id': 7724, 'date': '2013-05-31 11:40:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Kun Huang, you're right. I'll update that file and also doc/manpages/object-server.conf.5 and push a new chance

I was looking around if I should change any other documentation (i.e. what's shown on http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/) but couldn't find anything specific."}, {'account_id': 7724, 'date': '2013-05-31 19:57:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7724, 'date': '2013-05-31 19:59:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

'}, {'account_id': 2649, 'date': '2013-06-03 02:21:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It is understandable for the intention of limit bandwidth for rsync daemon in object replicator. But could it be implemented with more intelligence which means using this option when appropriate, not just a global option. Just a suggestion.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-03 14:02:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I've been told that --bwlimit doesn't work well with most Swift use cases, but I haven't verified that. Something about it limits at the per file level rather than the overall level or something like that. It would seem traffic shaping external to rsync might be a better option to promote.

That said, I guess it doesn't hurt to have the option to try it and maybe it works fine for some use cases. Have you tried this and found it to work well for you?"}, {'account_id': 7724, 'date': '2013-06-03 14:23:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

honestly I don't remember. and my approach was not very scientific.  We were saturating some of our switchports.  I did this change and a few others around the same time, and the problems disappeared, so I can't make any claims about how effective this is."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-06-03 19:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Yeah, it is arguable as to how well it will work, but I have no problem exposing it if people would like to try it out.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-04 13:55:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
ramdisk resize and image resize

Add some docs about resizing partitions on root with ramdisk

Give an example of how to use virt-resize.

Fix minor typo on front page.

Change-Id: I7afbb7093167b316e6c9f9ed89106ef4b0f76731
